(Code 1980, § 1-2-1; Ord. No. 01-08-02, 10-1-02; Ord. No. 06-01-03, 3-4-03) 
Sec. 2-137. - City attorney. 
    The city manager shall appoint a city attorney whose duties shall be to: 
(1)  Prosecute or defend any and all suits or actions at law or equity to which the city may be a party, or in which it may be interested, or which may be brought against, or by, any officer of the city or any person in the capacity of an officer of the city; 
(2)  See to the full enforcement of all judgments or decrees rendered or entered in favor of the city; 
(3)  See to the completion of all special assessment proceedings and condemnation proceedings; 
(4)  Draft or review any contract, lease or other document or instrument to which the city may be a party, and approve all ordinances and resolutions of the board as to form; 
(5)  Draft ordinances at the request of the board of commissioners covering any subject within the power of the city; 
(6)  Attend meetings of the board of commissioners upon request; and 
(7)  Perform any other duties required of him by G.S. 160A-173 and other laws and ordinances. 
(Code 1980, § 1-2-2; Ord. No. 06-01-03, 3-4-03) 
State Law reference- Duties of the attorney, G.S. 160A-173. 
Sec. 2-138. - Tax collector. 
    The city manager shall provide for the appointment of a tax collector, whose duties shall be to: 
(1)  Collect all taxes and assessments due to the city; 
(2)  Make an accounting to the city finance officer at the end of each month; 
(3)  Pay over to the city finance officer such money as is collected for the account of each separate fund according to the tax levy; 
(4)  Deliver a list of all unpaid taxes with the reason therefor as ascertainable to the board of commissioners; 
(5)  Supply the mayor and board of commissioners with any information as they may require relative to the performance of his duties; 
(6)  Make periodic reports to the board of commissioners listing therein all funds collected; 
(7)  Perform other duties required by G.S. 105-350 and other state law or as the city manager may direct. 
(Code 1980, § 1-2-3; Ord. No. 06-01-03, 3-4-03) 
State Law reference- Duties of tax collector, G.S. 105-349, 105-350. 
Sec. 2-139. - Finance officer. 
    The city manager shall provide for the appointment of a finance officer, whose duties shall be to: 
(1)  Keep the books and accounts of the city; 
(2)  Receive and disburse all monies of the city as required under state law; 
(3)  Countersign and preaudit all checks, drafts, contracts, purchase orders or other documents obligating city funds; 
(4)  Report to the board concerning the finances of the city, as it may require; 
(5)  Maintain all records of the bonded debt of the city and maintain sinking funds; 
(6)  Supervise the investment of idle funds; and 
(7)  Perform other duties assigned by the general statutes, the Charter or the city manager. 
(Code 1980, § 1-2-4; Ord. No. 06-01-03, 3-4-03) 
Cross reference- Finance, Ch. 5. 
State Law reference- Duties of the finance officer, G.S. 159-25; fiscal control generally, G.S. 159-7 et seq.

DIVISION 2. - POLICE DEPARTMENT[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Cross reference- Animals, Ch. 3; enforcement of the requirement for display of property numbers by the police department, § 4-181; bills and claims against the city shall be approved by the officer or employer responsible for the function or agency to which expense is charged, § 5-26; miscellaneous offenses, Ch. 8; nuisances, Ch. 9; personnel, Ch. 11; street safety duties of the chief of police, § 13-34; traffic and vehicles, Ch. 15. 
State Law reference- Municipal law enforcement in general, G.S. 160A-281 et seq. 

Sec. 2-171. - Created. 
    The city police department is hereby created subject to the terms, authority and conditions set out in this division. 
(Code 1980, § 2-1-1) 
Sec. 2-172. - Composition. 
    The police department of the city shall consist of a chief of police and officers and police officers of designated grade as the city manager deems necessary. 
(Code 1980, § 2-1-2; Ord. No. 06-01-03, 3-4-03) 
Sec. 2-173. - Police officers' duties generally. 
(a)  The chief of police and the members of the police department shall have the duty of enforcing all the ordinances of the city and the laws of this state within the city, and other duties as may be prescribed by ordinance. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of each member of the police force, upon information furnished him or upon his knowledge of any violation of the ordinances of the city or of the laws of this state, to secure proper warrants for the arrest and trial of any and all offenders against any ordinances or laws. 
(Code 1980, § 2-1-3) 
Sec. 2-174. - Hiring, discharging of personnel. 
    The city manager shall have the duty of hiring persons as may be necessary to man the police force of the city and to provide the city with adequate police protection, together with the duty of discharging such members. 
(Code 1980, § 2-1-4; Ord. No. 06-01-03, 3-4-03) 
Sec. 2-175. - Control and supervision. 
    The chief of police, subject to the general supervision of the city manager, is held responsible for the discipline, good order and proper conduct of the police department. 
(Code 1980, § 2-1-5; Ord. No. 06-01-03, 3-4-03) 
Sec. 2-176. - Conditions of employment. 
    Members of the police department shall be appointed by the city manager after due examination by the manager and based upon the results of the examination and interview. An appointee shall serve six (6) months probation. 
(Code 1980, § 2-1-6; Ord. No. 06-01-03, 3-4-03) 
State Law reference- Education and training standards for law enforcement officers, G.S. 17C-6(a)(2). 
Sec. 2-177. - Requirements of employment. 
    Every person appointed as a law enforcement officer shall: 
(1)  Be a citizen of the United States; 
(2)  Be at least twenty (20) years of age; 
(3)  Be of good moral character; 
(4)  Be fingerprinted and a search made of local, state and federal fingerprint files; 
(5)  Not have been convicted of a felony or an offense involving moral turpitude; 
(6)  Have a high school diploma or its equivalent; 
(7)  Pass an examination conducted by a physician employed by the city; 
(8)  Be interviewed and approved by the city manager; and 
(9)  Be certified in accordance with state law. 
(Code 1980, § 2-1-7; Ord. No. 06-01-03, 3-4-03) 
State Law reference- State law requires that law enforcement officers be certified by the criminal justice education and training standards commission, G.S. 17C-6, 17C-7. 
Sec. 2-178. - Specific duties of chief. 
(a)  The police chief of the city commands the police force under his order, and is responsible for its discipline and efficiency. Further, he shall recommend to the city manager the reforms and changes in the police department which practical experience shows should be instituted. Periodically the chief may be required to make out a statement of conduct of the affairs of the department, and shall include therein any suggestions for the improvement in the service or personnel of the department. 
(b)  Additional, specific functions of the chief of police are to: 
(1)  Issue to the force under his command such orders and directives as may be necessary to preserve the public peace, prevent crime, arrest offenders and to protect public and private property and persons in the city; 
(2)  Enforce the laws, ordinances, police regulations and executive orders applicable to his jurisdiction; 
(3)  Require the proper submission and handling of the necessary required reports. 
(Code 1980, § 2-1-8; Res. of 8-4-98, § 1; Ord. No. 06-01-03, 3-4-03; Res. No. 07-06, 2-6-07) 
Chapter 3 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Police department, § 2-171 et seq.; keeping of domestic animals restricted, § 17-207; keeping of farm animals restricted, § 17-208. 
State Law reference- Cruelty to animals, G.S. 14-360 et seq.; dogs, G.S. Ch. 67; rabies control, G.S. 130A-184 et seq.; authority to regulate, G.S. 160A-186 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 3-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Animal means any animate being except human beings, wild or domestic, which is endowed with the power of voluntary motion. 
    Animal control officer means the person or persons employed or designated by the city as its enforcement officer or officers empowered to carry the operation of the animal control department. 
    Animal control supervisor means the person employed by the city to carry out the operation of the animal control ordinance. 
    Animal shelter means any premises designated by the city for the purpose of impounding, quarantine, caring and disposing of any animal found running at large or in violation of this chapter. 
    At large means off the premises of the owner, when neither controlled by leash by the owner or some other person assuming responsibility of the owner's animal. 
    Attack. Any assault or battery by a dog upon a person or domestic animal to include biting, felling or toppling, tearing of clothing, or any other at which could reasonably cause physical injury to the person or domestic animal. The approach to a person by an unrestrained animal in a vicious, terrorizing or threatening manner or apparent attitude of attack, without the animal having been teased, molested, provoked, beaten, tortured, or otherwise harmed. 
    Bite by a dog. Any seizing, gripping or grasping, no matter how slight or momentary, by a dog between its jaws of the body parts of a person or domestic animal, so as to cause physical injury to such person or domestic animal. 
    Cat means a domestic feline of either sex. 
    Dangerous animal. Any animal that has demonstrated a fierce or dangerous propensity or tendency to do any act which may endanger persons or property and/or any non-domesticated animal indigenous to the State of North Carolina, including hybrid animals that are part wild. This would include, but not be limited to, any dog which assaults, bites, attacks or inflicts serious injury on a human being without provocation on public or private property and/or which has killed or injured a pet or domestic animal without provocation. No dog is dangerous pursuant to this definition if the person it attacked was teasing, molesting, provoking, beating, torturing, abusing or assaulting the dog, or has done so in the past. Nor shall a dog be considered dangerous pursuant to this definition if it has attacked or injured a pet or domesticated animal in defense of an attack by another animal or if it is protecting or defending its young. 
    Dog means a domestic canine of either sex. 
    Impoundment means to take custody of a domestic animal, under legal authority, in a confined area or pen. 
    Kitten means a feline between birth through four (4) months, before permanent teeth appear. 
    Lost means an animal reported by its owner to be off the owner's property and whereabouts unknown. 
    Owner is defined as any person, group of persons, firm, partnership, corporation or other entity owning, keeping, having charge of or taking care of an animal or allowing an animal to remain on his premises or property. 
    Puppy means a dog between birth and four (4) or five (5) months, before the permanent teeth appear. 
    Quarantine means to confine a domestic animal under legal authority to specifically prevent a suspected rabid animal's contact with other animals or humans. 
    Rabid means infected with the animal virus rhabdovirus where existence of infection is ascertained by a trained person observing fanatical behavior or a frothing at the jaws or determination is made by laboratory analysis of the severed, intact animal head, maintained on ice but not frozen, for viral antigen or negri bodies. 
    Restraining of vicious or dangerous animal means that the animal is: 
(1)  Controlled by a leash; 
(2)  On or within any vehicle being driven or parked on the street and unable to bite persons outside the vehicle; 
(3)  Confined within the property limits of its owner or keeper. 
    Stray means an animal not under the owner's restraint or on the owner's property. 
    Vaccination means the administration of rabies vaccine by a licensed veterinarian approved by the United States Bureau of Animal Industry, the state department of agriculture, and the state commission of health services. 
(Code 1980, § 6-5-1; Res. No. 06-28, §§ 1-3, 7-11-06; Res. No. 2015-03, § 1, 3-3-15) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 3-2. - Nuisances. 
    The keeping or maintenance of any animal which by prolonged and habitual barking, howling or whining or other actions which cause serious annoyance to neighboring residents and interfere with the reasonable use and enjoyment of the premises occupied by such residents or with reasonable use and enjoyment of the public streets, sidewalks or other public areas is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and shall be abated as provided in section 3-4. Actions deemed prima facie evidence of a public nuisance are as follows: 
(1)  Any animal which damages the property of anyone other than its owner, including but not limited to turning over garbage containers or damaging gardens, flowers or vegetables; 
(2)  Any animal which is a vicious animal as described in section 3-1; 
(3)  Animals maintained in an environment of unsanitary conditions in violation of section 3-3; 
(4)  Any animal which is diseased and not under veterinary care; 
(5)  Any animal which jumps on, chases, snaps at, attacks or threatens pedestrians, bicycles or vehicles, joggers or runners and is not in an enclosure or under restraint; 
(6)  Failure to confine a female dog while in heat in a building or secure enclosure in such a manner that she will not be in contact with another dog, nor creating a nuisance; provided, this section shall not be construed to prohibit the intentional breeding of animals within an enclosed area on the premises of the owner of an animal which is being bred. 
(Code 1980, § 6-5-15) 
Cross reference- Nuisances, Ch. 9. 
Sec. 3-3. - Maintenance of lots, pens, etc. 
    Every person who owns or maintains a pen, lot, shelter or other place where animals are kept shall maintain it in a sanitary manner, and shall maintain it in accordance with the General Statutes. 
(Code 1980, § 6-5-12) 
Sec. 3-4. - Abatement of nuisances; citations. 
(a)  The local animal control officer and police chief or his agent are hereby empowered to issue citations to any person if there is probable cause to believe that such person has violated any of the provisions of this chapter. Citations so issued may be served in person on the violator by the police chief or his representative or they may be mailed to the person by certified mail if such person cannot be readily found. Any citation so served or mailed shall direct the violator to make payment of the fine provided therein to the city clerk on or before a specific day and hour named in the citation and to present evidence of the remedy of any violation of this chapter. The period specified shall not be less than seventy-two (72) hours after service or delivery to the violator. If the violator is served by mail, the violator shall have six (6) days after the return receipt date to respond to the citation. 
(b)  If the violator does not appear in response to the citation, the police chief shall forthwith have a complaint entered against such person and secure and issue a warrant for his arrest. The arrest shall be for the violation of the section of this chapter charged in the citation, and upon conviction the defendant shall be subject to the penalties prescribed by section 1-15. 
(c)  The police chief may issue a warning citation, without fine, in the case where in his opinion a violation of this chapter may be remedied without the necessity for criminal prosecution. A warning citation may not be issued in the case where any animal is endangered or in any case where the public safety is endangered. 
(d)  Violation of this section may subject the offender to penalties or fines. The civil penalties have been established to cover the cost of enforcement of this section in accordance with section 1-15 of this Code. The civil penalty shall be as published in the fee schedule adopted by the board of commissioners and modified from time to time. 
(Code 1980, § 6-5-16; Ord. of 9-6-94; Res. No. 2008-24, 7-1-08; Res. No. 2015-03, § 1, 3-3-15) 
Sec. 3-5. - Formal citizen complaint. 
    Upon receipt of a written complaint on a form provided by the city, made under oath before an individual authorized by law to take acknowledgments, setting forth the nature and the date of the act, the apparent owner of the animal, the address of the apparent owner and a description of the animal doing such act, the police chief shall investigate any complaint to determine whether the act complained of violates this chapter. The complaint shall further contain a provision stating that the complainant shall appear as a witness in a court of law if called upon to do so. 
(Code 1980, § 6-5-17) 
Sec. 3-6. - Injury to birds. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to injure, kill or attempt to injure or kill any wild bird or to rob or destroy any wild bird's nest within the city limits. 
(Res. No. 2015-03, § 1, 3-3-15) 
Secs. 3-7-3-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2. 

Sec. 3-31. - Animal control supervisor-Appointment; scope. 
(a)  There is hereby created in the city the office of animal control officer, who shall serve in the police department. 
(b)  The operation of this chapter and the animal control program shall be under the jurisdiction of the Boiling Spring Lakes Police Department. 
(Code 1980, § 6-5-2; Res. of 8-4-98, § 2; Res. No. 07-06, 2-6-07; Res. No. 2015-03, § 1, 3-3-15) 
Sec. 3-32. - Same-Powers and duties. 
(a)  The animal control officer shall have the power of arrest and be responsible for the enforcement within the city of all state laws and local ordinances pertaining to the ownership and control of all animals and shall cooperate with all other law enforcement officers operating within the county in fulfilling this responsibility. 
(b)  The animal control officer shall implement and enforce the provisions of the state rabies law and the dog warden law including but not limited to the following activities: 
(1)  Collect and impound stray animals; 
(2)  Canvass area of the city for vaccination and tax listing of animals; 
(3)  Assist licensed veterinarians in conducting all quarterly rabies clinics sponsored by the health department within the county; 
(4)  Investigate animal bite cases and either confine or arrange for confinement of the biting animal for a ten-day observation period. 
(Code 1980, § 6-5-3; Res. of 8-4-98, § 3; Res. No. 2015-03, § 1, 3-3-15) 
Secs. 3-33-3-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DOGS AND CATS 

Sec. 3-51. - Rabies vaccination. 
    As required by G.S. 130A-185, all dogs and cats four (4) months of age or older shall be vaccinated against rabies. Only animal rabies vaccine licensed by the United States Department of Agriculture and approved by the state commission for health services of the department of environment, health and natural resources shall be administered to animals in the city. 
(Code 1980, § 6-5-11) 
Sec. 3-52. - Registration and fee. 
(a)  All dogs kept within the city limits by residents shall be registered with the police department annually in January of each year. Upon registration, all dog owners will be provided a numbered tag by the police department. The tag shall be attached to the collar of the dog as evidence that the dog has been registered. The dog tag will only be issued if proof of rabies vaccination is provided at time of registration. 
(b)  The city shall collect an annual registration fee as set forth in the city's fee schedule maintained at City Hall and modified from time to time as deemed necessary by the board of commissioners. 
(c)  Violation of this section may subject the offender to penalties, both civil and criminal. The civil penalties have been established to cover the cost of enforcement of this section in accordance with section 1-15 of this ordinance. The civil penalty shall be as published in the fee schedule adopted by the board of commissioners and modified from time to time. 
(Code 1980, § 6-5-10; Ord. No. 01-08-02, 10-1-02; Res. No. 2005-2, 1-4-05; Res. No. 2008-24, 7-1-08) 
Sec. 3-53. - Exemption from state law. 
    Pursuant to Public Laws, 1949, chapter 137, no provisions pertaining to dog taxes shall apply to the city and the city is specifically exempted therefrom. 
(Code 1980, § 6-5-13) 
Sec. 3-54. - Wearing of collars, tags. 
    Every dog and cat shall be required at all times to wear a collar to which has been affixed a rabies vaccination tag. Every dog shall have a city tax tag attached to the collar. 
(Code 1980, § 6-5-10) 
Sec. 3-55. - Running at large. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any owner of a dog to allow it to be off the premises of the owner unless such pet is wearing a collar with a rabies tag and a dog tax tag. If any dog leaves the premises of the owner, it must be on a leash and under physical restraint. 
(b)  Violation of this section may subject the offender to penalties or fines. The civil penalties have been established to cover the cost of enforcement of this section in accordance with section 1-15 of this Code. 
The civil penalty shall be as published in the fee schedule adopted by the board of commissioners and modified from time to time. If appropriate, the offender shall also be responsible for the cost to repair or replace any damaged property that may be incurred as a result of a violation of this section, said cost being added to the penalty. 
(Code 1980, § 6-5-14; Res. of 11-14-95; Ord. No. 01-08-02, 10-1-02; Res. No. 06-06, § 1, 2-7-06; Res. No. 2008-24, 7-1-08; Res. No. 2015-03, § 1, 3-3-15) 
Sec. 3-56. - Reserved. 
Sec. 3-57. - Cleaning up after dogs and cats. 
    Any person owning, keeping or harboring any dog or cat shall promptly remove and dispose of all feces left by the dog or cat on public property and on any private property not owned or lawfully occupied by such person within the city. 
(Res. No. 2015-03, § 1, 3-3-15) 
Sec. 3-58. - Unlawful to trap dogs and cats. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, organization or agency to trap, by cage or other device, a dog or cat. The City of Boiling Spring Lakes will make available for loan, humane traps designed for the capture of dogs or cats. These traps can be issued to a resident or property owner for period no longer than ten (10) days. 
(1)  The animal control officer shall have the sole authority and discretion to issue a trap for this purpose. Any dog or cat trapped pursuant to a permit shall be treated humanely and promptly turned over to the animal control officer. 
(2)  It shall not be unlawful for a person to apprehend a dog or cat on his/her property by hand, provided, however, the person must notify the animal control officer within twenty-four (24) hours of catching the animal. Any dog or cat trapped or captured by hand shall be treated humanely and promptly turned over to the animal control officer. 
(Res. No. 2015-03, § 1, 3-3-15) 
Secs. 3-59-3-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - IMPOUNDMENT 

Sec. 3-76. - Generally; impoundment of animals running at large. 
    It shall be the duty of the animal control officer to seize any untagged animal running at large contrary to the provisions of this chapter and impound such animal. If any dangerous or vicious animal is found at large, whether such animal is tagged or untagged, and cannot be safely restrained, captured, transported and impounded, such animal may be immobilized by the animal control officer. 
(Code 1980, § 6-5-5; Res. No. 06-25, § 1, 7-11-06; Res. No. 2015-03, § 1, 3-3-15) 
Sec. 3-77. - Confinement or leashing of vicious animals. 
    Refer to chapter 3, article V, potentially dangerous or vicious dogs. 
(Code 1980, § 6-5-6; Res. No. 06-25, § 2, 7-11-06) 
Sec. 3-78. - Records; notice to owner. 
    A complete registry shall be maintained on the breed, color, sex and size of all animals impounded. If the ownership of an animal can be determined, the owner shall be notified within three (3) days after impounding. The owner may reclaim the animal pursuant to section 3-79. 
(Code 1980, § 6-5-7) 
Sec. 3-79. - Care of impounded animals; redemption; unredeemed animals. 
    The animal control officer is authorized to obtain suitable maintenance and care for any impounded animal from any available source. The owner of any animal impounded and cared for under this article shall within five (5) days of impoundment redeem the animal upon payment of all costs of maintenance, transportation and care plus the redemption fees provided in section 3-80. The animal shall be transferred to the county animal shelter for disposition not inconsistent with the provisions of the General Statutes. 
(Code 1980, § 6-5-4; Ord. No. 01-08-02, 10-1-02; Res. No. 2015-03, § 1, 3-3-15) 
Sec. 3-80. - Fees. 
    A fee shall be charged for impound and care that has been established to cover the costs of enforcement of this section. The fee shall be as published in the fee schedule adopted by the board of commissioners and modified from time to time. 
(Code 1980, § 6-5-8; Ord. of 9-6-94; Ord. No. 06-01-03, 3-4-03; Res. No. 06-06, § 2, 2-7-06; Res. No. 2008-24, 7-1-08) 
Sec. 3-81. - Obstruction, interference with impoundment procedures. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct or interfere in any manner with the restraint, capture, transportation or impoundment of any dog, cat or animal found to be in violation of any provisions of this chapter. In addition, it shall be unlawful for any person to release or attempt to release any dog, cat or animal that has been impounded except as hereinbefore provided. 
(Code 1980, § 6-5-9) 
Secs. 3-82-3-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - POTENTIALLY DANGEROUS OR VICIOUS DOGS 

Sec. 3-101. - Determination that a dog is dangerous, potentially dangerous or vicious. 
(a)  Generally. The determination whether or not such dog is dangerous, potentially dangerous or vicious, as herein defined, shall be made by the Animal Control Officer of the City of Boiling Spring Lakes (hereinafter referred to as the "ACO") or such alternate hearing official as the Board of Commissioners of the City of Boiling Spring Lakes (hereinafter referred to as the "commissioners") may from time to time appoint. 
(a1)  Request for determination hearing. Any person owning, keeping or harboring a dog, who is required to make a report pursuant to this article or otherwise suspects that such dog is dangerous or vicious, may request a determination hearing by written application to the ACO setting forth such suspicions. Upon receipt of such a request, the ACO shall investigate the matter and conduct a determination hearing upon notice as provided in this section. Such voluntary submission to a determination hearing shall relieve such person from the assessment of a civil penalty under the provisions of this article for any violation of this article occurring between the date of the event causing such person to suspect the dog is dangerous or vicious and the date of the determination hearing, provided that such request is made no later than five (5) days after the event arousing suspicion. 
(b)  Investigation and preliminary findings. Upon receipt of a report required by this article or of a complaint that some person owns, keeps or harbors a dangerous, potentially dangerous, or vicious dog, as defined herein, the ACO shall make or cause to be made an investigation and, on the results of such investigation, make a written preliminary finding that there is or is not reasonable cause to hold a hearing to determine whether or not the dog which is the subject of investigation is dangerous, potentially dangerous, or vicious, as herein defined. 
(c)  Determination hearing upon notice. Upon a preliminary finding that there is reasonable cause to hold a determination hearing, a hearing by the ACO, or his designee, shall be held upon notice to the owner, keeper or harborer of the dog concerned. Such hearing shall be held as expeditiously as possible and, in any event, not more than twenty (20) days after such finding. 
(d)  Determination and order. Following the hearing, the hearing officer shall issue a written determination stating that the suspect dog is or is not a dangerous, potentially dangerous, or vicious dog. If the determination is made that the suspect dog is dangerous, potentially dangerous, or vicious, the written determination shall order compliance with the appropriate provisions of this article. If it is determined that violations of the provisions of this article occurred, the hearing officer shall assess appropriate civil penalties for such violations and may elect to pursue other remedies authorized by law. 
(e)  Appeals from determinations. The owner, keeper or harborer of a dog determined hereby to be dangerous, potentially dangerous, or vicious, or any person bitten or attacked by a dog determined hereby not to be dangerous, potentially dangerous, or vicious, or the owner of a domestic animal injured by such dog may appeal such determination, in writing, within three (3) days, to the commissioners or to such appeals board as the commissioners may, by resolution, appoint to hear such appeals. The appeals board shall hold a hearing within ten (10) days. Membership on an appeals board shall include, but not be limited to, persons with knowledge and experience in the matter of dog behavior, such as law enforcement officers, veterinarians, veterinarian technicians, private breeders, dog trainers, or private dog owners. The ruling of the commissioners or appointed appeals board shall be final, subject only to a petition for certiorari to the Superior Court of Brunswick County, filed within ten (10) days of the date of the final determination by the commissioners or the appeals board in accordance with Chapter 67, Article 1A, G.S. 67-4.1, Definitions and procedures. 
(f)  Reserved. 
(Res. No. 06-25, § 3, 7-11-06; Res. No. 2015-03, § 1, 3-3-15) 
Sec. 3-102. - Registration required. 
(a)  Generally. Any person owning, keeping, or harboring a dog determined as set forth above to be dangerous, potentially dangerous, or vicious shall register such dog with the ACO within five (5) days of such determination. In lieu of a determination hearing, an owner, keeper or harborer of a dog suspected of being dangerous, potentially dangerous, or vicious may register such dog voluntarily; such registration shall be an admission and determination that the dog is dangerous, potentially dangerous, or vicious. 
(b)  Relief from civil penalty. Voluntary registration of a dangerous, potentially dangerous, or vicious dog by the owner, keeper or harborer thereof within thirty (30) days of the effective date of this article or prior to the determination that a suspect dog is dangerous, potentially dangerous, or vicious or within five (5) days of an event establishing reasonable cause to believe that a dog is dangerous or vicious or of the acquisition of a dangerous or vicious dog, whichever later occurs, shall relieve such person from the assessment of a civil penalty under the provisions of this article for any violation of this article occurring between such date, event or acquisition and the date of registration. 
(c)  Permanent identification mark required. Each dog registered as set forth above shall be assigned by the ACO a registration number, which shall be affixed to the dog by permanent tattoo or some other permanent means by or at the expense of the owner, keeper or harborer of the dog. No person shall remove such identification mark once it is assigned and affixed. 
(Res. No. 06-25, § 3, 7-11-06) 
Sec. 3-103. - Permit required. 
(a)  Generally. After registration of a dangerous dog or a determination that the dog is dangerous, no person shall own, keep or harbor such dog thereafter within the territorial jurisdiction of the City of Bolling Spring Lakes without applying for and obtaining a permit from the ACO. 
(b)  Issuance of permit. A permit shall be issued by the ACO only upon submission of a complete, verified application, payment of the permit fee, and a finding by the ACO, or the designee thereof, that arrangements for housing of the dog and other public health and safety provisions required by this article are in place, and that each dangerous dog for which a permit is issued does not pose an unreasonable threat to the public health, safety and general welfare, if the permittee complies with the provisions of this article and the conditions of the permit. Each permit shall be conditioned on continued compliance with the provisions of this article and other provisions of the City Code, on continued compliance with and maintenance of the arrangements for housing and safety set forth in the permit application, and any special conditions that the ACO deems reasonably necessary to protect the public health, safety and general welfare in view of the particular circumstances and history of the dog concerned. 
(c)  Temporary permits. Following the registration of a dangerous or vicious dog or the apprehension and confinement of a suspect dog pursuant to the provisions of this article, the ACO may issue, upon application and for good cause shown, a temporary permit allowing the owner, keeper or harborer of a registered dangerous dog or dog suspected of being dangerous to retain possession of such dog or to confine such dog at a veterinary facility or kennel approved by such officer. A temporary permit also may be issued to allow the transport of a vicious dog from the territorial jurisdiction of the City of Boiling Spring Lakes. A temporary permit shall be issued subject to the same conditions to which a regular permit is subject and to any other conditions the ACO deems to be necessary to protect the public health, safety and welfare in a manner consistent with the provisions of this article. A temporary permit shall be valid only until the earlier of its revocation or the issuance or denial of a permit under the provisions of subsection (b) of this section. 
(d)  Term of permits and renewal thereof. No permit shall be issued under subsection (b) of this section for a period in excess of three (3) years and may, in the discretion of the ACO, be issued for a lesser period. Permits may be renewed, subject to the same terms and conditions required for initial permits. 
(e)  Revocation of permits. The ACO may, upon notice and hearing and for good cause shown, revoke any permit or modify any terms, conditions or provisions thereof. In the event that the ACO deems it necessary to protect the public health or safety from any imminent threat or danger thereto, the ACO may, without hearing, suspend any permit or any portion thereof for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days. Good cause for revocation or modification of a permit shall include, without limitation, the violation of or failure to comply with any provision of this article or with any term, condition or provision of a permit. 
(f)  Inspections. The ACO shall cause inspections to be made of the premises of a permittee to determine compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(g)  Insurance. Every person owning, keeping or harboring a dog that has been declared dangerous, potentially dangerous, or vicious shall purchase and maintain a policy of liability insurance covering any injury or property damage caused by the dog. Minimum policy limits shall be: One hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) personal injury or property damage, per occurrence. The owner, keeper or harborer of a dog that has been declared dangerous, potentially dangerous, or vicious shall cause a certificate of insurance to be furnished to the ACO annually by their insurance carrier. Every calendar day that the required insurance is not in full force and effect shall constitute a Class III violation of this article pursuant to subsection 3-106(a). 
(Res. No. 06-25, § 3, 7-11-06) 
Sec. 3-104. - Regulation of dangerous and vicious dogs; security and restraint requirements. 
    No person shall own, keep or harbor a dangerous, potentially dangerous, or vicious dog, as herein defined, except in compliance with the following and other provisions of this article: 
(1)  a.  Once a dog has been found to meet the criteria for a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog, the owner of the animal must take certain measures to ensure the animal does not escape from restraint before possession is returned. Said dogs shall be restrained in the following manner: 
1.  The dog must be kept in a secure enclosure that has a cement floor. The enclosure cannot be smaller than ten (10) feet by ten (10) feet. 
2.  The kennel must have a cement floor and the fencing must be securely attached to the cement to prevent the animal from digging under or moving the pen off of the cement floor. 
3.  The kennel must have a continuous top that completely covers the enclosure. 
4.  Any entrance to the enclosure must be secured with a combination or keyed lock. 
5.  The owner or keeper of any dangerous dog must post signs on the property where the animal is kept letting citizens know that there is such an animal that is being kept on the property. 
6.  While outside a building or enclosure described above, securely leashed with a leash no longer than four (4) feet in length in the hands of and under the control of a responsible adult person capable of such control and muzzled by a muzzling device sufficient to prevent such dog from biting persons or other animals. 
b.  The enclosure where a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog is being kept shall be inspected by the chief of police or his designee to ensure that all requirements are met. 
c.  Any owner or keeper of a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog that does not meet the requirements will be notified that the enclosure is insufficient and must comply before the dog will be allowed to remain or be kept in the enclosure. 
d.  If the owner of a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog transfers ownership or possession of the dog to another person, the owner shall provide written notice: 
1.  To the chief of police, stating the name and address of the owner of the dog; and 
2.  To the person taking possession of the dog, specifying the dog's dangerous behavior and the chief of police or review board's determination. 
e.  A violation of this section shall, in addition to the maximum penalties for local ordinances provided by law, be subject to a five hundred dollar ($500.00) fine. Each day the dog shall not be adequately restrained shall be considered a separate violation. 
(Res. No. 06-25, § 3, 7-11-06; Res. No. 2015-03, § 1, 3-3-15) 
Sec. 3-105. - Apprehension and confinement of dangerous and vicious dogs. 
(a)  Apprehension and surrender. Upon a preliminary finding that there is reasonable cause to hold a determination hearing pertaining to a suspect dog; upon registration of a dog to be dangerous, potentially dangerous, or vicious; or there is reasonable cause to believe that a dangerous, potentially dangerous, or vicious dog is being kept or harbored within the territorial jurisdiction of the City of Boiling Spring Lakes in violation of this article or the terms, conditions and provisions of a permit issued hereunder, animal control officers and law enforcement officers of the City of Boiling Spring Lakes shall apprehend and confine such dog. It shall be a violation of this article to fall or refuse to surrender such dog to such officers upon their lawful demand. The officer apprehending or taking custody of such a dog shall deliver the same to the county animal pound for confinement. 
(b)  Confinement. A dog apprehended by or surrendered to an animal control officer or law enforcement officer as provided herein shall be confined in the county animal pound or, upon request of the owner, keeper or harborer of the dog or a permittee hereunder, at a private veterinary facility or kennel approved by the ACO. Confinement shall be subject to the following provisions: 
(1)  Costs of confinement. Confinement shall be at the expense of the owner, keeper or harborer of the dog subject to this article, which shall be the permittee if a permit has been issued hereunder. The costs of confinement at the county animal pound shall be paid by the person liable therefor at a daily rate established by the ACO. The costs of confinement at a veterinary facility or kennel shall be paid by the person liable therefor pursuant to the terms of the agreement between such person and the proprietor of such facility or kennel. In no event shall the City of Boiling Spring Lakes be liable for or pay for confinement at such private facility or kennel. 
(2)  Release from confinement. Release from confinement under the provisions of this article shall be authorized only upon registration of the dog concerned and issuance as provided herein of a permit or temporary permit allowing such release. Release from the county animal pound shall not be allowed until costs of confinement of such dog, any registration and permit fees for such dog, and any civil penalties assessed in connection with such dog have been paid in full. 
(3)  Disposition of unclaimed or abandoned dogs. The following categories of dogs confined in the Brunswick County animal pound pursuant to this article shall be deemed abandoned and disposed of in accordance with the provisions of this article and the rules and regulations of the pound: 
a.  Any dog which remains unclaimed by the owner, keeper or harborer thereof or a permittee thereof for a period more than ten (10) days or a period of lawful quarantine, whichever is longer. 
b.  Any dog claimed by its owner, keeper or harborer, which is confined for a period in excess of ten (10) days, or a period of lawful quarantine, whichever is longer, during which no application for a permit or temporary permit or no lawful action to obtain release is initiated; provided that the ACO shall extend such time upon a showing of justifiable delay in such action by the owner, keeper, harborer or permittee thereof. 
(Res. No. 06-25, § 3, 7-11-06) 
Sec. 3-106. - Violations, penalties and other remedies. 
(a)  Violations. Each act or conduct prohibited by a provision of this article and each failure to comply with a mandatory provision of this article shall constitute a violation of this article. Each day's continuing act or conduct prohibited hereby and each day's continuing failure to comply shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. Violations of this article shall subject the violator to civil penalties and to other remedies allowed by law. For the purposes of assessing civil penalties, violations of this article are classified as follows: 
(1)  Class I violations: 
a.  Failure to report an event for which a report is required under this article. 
b.  Failure to register a dangerous or vicious dog as required by this article. 
c.  Any other violation of this article not otherwise classified in this section. 
(2)  Class II violations: 
a.  Keeping or harboring a vicious dog within the territorial jurisdiction of the City of Boiling Spring Lakes in violation of this article. 
b.  Keeping or harboring a dangerous dog within the territorial jurisdiction of the City of Boiling Spring Lakes in violation of terms, conditions and provisions of a permit or of the housing and restraint requirements of this article. 
c.  Failure to surrender a dangerous dog or a dog that there is reasonable cause to believe is dangerous to an animal control officer or law enforcement officer for confinement as required by this article. 
d.  Willfully or negligently allowing a dangerous or vicious dog to leave the premises where it has been kept or harbored. 
(3)  Class III violations: 
a.  Willfully or negligently allowing a dangerous or vicious dog to leave the premises where it has been kept or harbored, when such dog has thereafter committed an attack or a biting. 
b.  Refusal to surrender a vicious dog to an animal control officer or law enforcement officer for confinement as required by this article. 
c.  Failure to maintain insurance pursuant to section 3-103 of this article. 
(b)  Violation of this section may subject the offender to penalties or fines. The civil penalties have been established to cover the cost of enforcement of this section in accordance with section 1-15 of this Code. The civil penalty shall be as published in the fee schedule adopted by the board of commissioners and modified from time to time. 
(c)  Other remedies. In addition to the assessment of civil penalties, this article may be enforced by any one (1) or more of the remedies set forth in Chapter 153A, Section 153A-123 of the General Statutes of North Carolina. 
(d)  State law violations. 
(1)  Nothing in this article shall be construed to prevent the pursuit by an animal control officer or any other persons of remedies under the provisions of Chapter 67, Division IA, of the North Carolina General Statutes for violations of that state statute or to prevent actions for civil damages pursuant to that statute. 
(2)  The ACO is designated as the person to be responsible for making the determination required under N.C.G.S. § 67-4-1(c). To make such determinations, the ACO shall follow the procedure set forth herein for determinations pursuant to this article. 
(3)  The commissioners or the appeals board established under the provisions of this article is designated as the appellate board to hear appeals of determinations made pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 67-4-1(c). 
(Res. No. 06-25, § 3, 7-11-06; Res. No. 2008-24, 7-1-08) 
Sec. 3-107. - Administrative provisions. 
(a)  Responsibility. The ACO shall be responsible for the administration and enforcement of this article. THE ACO shall promulgate departmental rules and regulations for such administration and enforcement which shall be effective upon approval by the commissioners. 
(b)  Citations assessing civil penalties. The ACO shall have authority to investigate alleged or suspected violations of this article and, upon the determination by such person, based on observation or other evidence, that a violation has occurred, each such person shall have the authority to issue a written citation for violation of this article and therein assess a civil penalty in the amount due. Such citation shall be served on the violator by an animal control officer, a law enforcement officer of the City of Boiling Spring Lakes, a deputy sheriff of Brunswick County, or other lawful process server, or by certified mail, return receipt requested, addressed to the last known address of the violator. Service shall be complete upon delivery in person to the violator or his agent or upon execution of a receipt for the certified mail by the violator or his agent in the event of such service. If a civil penalty duly assessed is not paid when due, the ACO shall initiate an action in a court of competent jurisdiction to collect such amount due. 
(c)  Authority to enter upon premises. For the purposes of making an investigation of a dog alleged or suspected of being dangerous or vicious, of apprehending a dog determined to be dangerous or vicious or a dog concerning which there is reasonable cause to believe is dangerous or vicious, of conducting an investigation of a violation of this article, or of serving a citation upon a person for violation of this article, animal control officers shall have the authority to enter into and upon all premises, to include dwellings, dwelling units, rooming units, barns and other outbuildings, any part or curtilage thereof, and any yard or other enclosure in which a suspect dog or dangerous or vicious dog is kept or harbored. Nothing in this section shall be construed to free an animal control officer from any requirement to obtain the consent of the owner or occupant of the premises concerned or to obtain an administrative search warrant pursuant to [N.C.G.S.] § 15-27-2 or other provisions of the General Statutes of North Carolina or otherwise to view or enter into or upon such premises in a manner prescribed by law. 
(d)  Authority to immobilize or kill a dangerous or vicious dog. 
(1)  If in the course of investigating, apprehending or otherwise taking custody of a dangerous or vicious dog, or a dog which there is reasonable cause to believe is dangerous or vicious, such dog is unrestrained and an animal control officer or a law enforcement officer has reasonable cause to believe the dog poses an imminent risk of serious physical injury or death to any person or domestic animal, said officer shall have the authority to render such dog immobile by means of tranquilizers or other safe drugs or, if that is not safely or timely possible under the circumstances, then said officer shall have the authority humanely to kill said dog. 
(2)  If in the course of confinement in the county animal pound of a dangerous or vicious dog, or a dog which there is reasonable cause to believe is dangerous or vicious, such dog cannot be cared for or handled without risk of serious physical injury or death to persons caring for or handling such dog or to other animals in the pound, an animal control officer shall have the authority to render such dog immobile by means of tranquilizers or other safe drugs or, if that is not safely or timely possible under the circumstances, then said officer shall have the authority to humanely kill said dog. 
(3)  An animal control officer shall have the authority humanely to kill any dog being investigated under the provisions of this article at the request of or with the consent of its owner, keeper or harborer. 
(Res. No. 06-25, § 3, 7-11-06) 
Chapter 4 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Community appearance commission to formulate and recommend to the planning board or board of commissioners the adoption of amendments to the zoning regulations, subdivision regulations and other ordinances regulating the use of property, § 2-81(a); regulations for house moving, § 13-1; maintenance of buildings, § 17-204; swimming pool fence requirements in the zoning ordinance, § 17-206; landscape requirements in the zoning ordinance, § 17-241 et seq.; building and manufactured housing regulations in the zoning ordinance, § 17-256 et seq. 
State Law reference- Building inspection, G.S. 160A-411 et seq.; state building code and building code council, G.S. 143-136 et seq.; warrants to conduct inspections, G.S. 15-27.2; fire limits, G.S. 160A-435 et seq.; minimum housing standards, G.S. 160A-441 et seq.; fire escapes, G.S. 69-8 et seq.; contractors, G.S. Ch. 87; public building contracts, G.S. 143-128 et seq.; manufactured housing and mobile homes, G.S. 143-143.8 et seq.; North Carolina Code Officials Qualification Board, G.S. 143-151.8 et seq.; enforcement of building code insulation and energy utilization standards, G.S. 143-151.26 et seq.; technical ordinances, G.S. 160A-76; inspection of buildings for fire hazards, G.S. 69-4; regulating and licensing businesses, trades, etc., G.S. 160A-194. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 4-1. - Scope of chapter and adopted codes. 
    The provisions of this chapter and of the regulatory codes adopted in this chapter shall apply to the following: 
(1)  The location, design, materials, equipment, construction, reconstruction, alteration, repair, maintenance, moving, demolition, removal, use and occupancy of every building or structure or any appurtenances connected or attached to such building or structure; 
(2)  The installation, erection, alteration, repair, use and maintenance of plumbing systems consisting of house sewers, building drains, waste and vent systems, hot and cold water supply systems, and all fixtures and appurtenances thereof; 
(3)  The installation, erection, alteration, repair, use and maintenance of mechanical systems consisting of heating, ventilating, air conditioning and refrigeration systems, fuel-burning equipment and appurtenances thereof; and 
(4)  The installation, erection, alteration, repair, use and maintenance of electrical systems and appurtenances thereof. 
(Code 1980, § 7-1-1) 
Secs. 4-2-4-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 4-26. - General requirements for new construction projects. 
    All new construction projects located within the jurisdiction for the city shall comply with the following: 
(1)  Temporary toilet facilities. All temporary toilet facilities shall be located on the property they serve and not on public street rights-of-way. The facility will be installed on the property as follows: 
a.  With the door facing away from the public street or if a corner lot, at a forty-five (45) degree angle; 
b.  Away from the construction access point; and 
c.  Enclosed on three (3) sides by lattice secured to twelve (12) foot 4 × 4 post installed a minimum of three (3) feet in the ground. 
(Res. No. 2008-08, § 2, 3-4-08) 
Secs. 4-27-4-35. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - INSPECTION DEPARTMENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Departments, § 2-161 et seq.; bills and claims against the city shall be approved by the officer or employer responsible for the function or agency to which expense is charged, § 5-26. 
State Law reference- Municipal inspection department, G.S. 160A-411 et seq. 

Sec. 4-36. - Composition, organization. 
    The inspection department of the city shall consist of a building inspector and may also include a plumbing inspector, a heating and air conditioning inspector, an electrical inspector and such other inspectors or deputy or assistant inspectors as may be authorized by the city manager. The city manager at his discretion, may designate a department head, or may impose the duties of building inspector upon the director of public utilities. 
(Code 1980, § 7-1-21; Ord. No. 06-01-03, 3-4-03) 
Sec. 4-37. - General duties. 
    It shall be the duty of the inspection department to enforce all of the provisions of this chapter and of the regulatory codes adopted herein, and to make all inspections necessary to determine whether or not the provisions of this chapter and the codes are being met. 
(Code 1980, § 7-1-22) 
Sec. 4-38. - Conflicts of interest. 
    No officer or employee of the inspection department shall be financially interested in the furnishing of labor, material or appliances for the construction, alteration or maintenance of a building or any part thereof, or in the making of plans or specifications therefor, unless he is the owner of the building. No officer or employee of the inspection department shall engage in any work which is inconsistent with his duties or with the interests of the city. 
(Code 1980, § 7-1-23) 
Sec. 4-39. - Records, reports. 
    The inspection department shall keep complete, permanent and accurate records in convenient form of all applications received, permits issued, inspections and reinspections made, and all other work and activities of the inspection department. Periodic reports shall be submitted to the city manager, board of commissioners and to other agencies, as required. 
(Code 1980, § 7-1-24; Ord. No. 06-01-03, 3-4-03) 
Sec. 4-40. - Inspection procedure. 
(a)  Inspections. The inspection department shall inspect all buildings and structures and work therein for which a permit of any kind has been issued as often as necessary in order to determine whether the work complies with the appropriate codes. When deemed necessary by the appropriate inspector, materials and assemblies may be inspected at the point of manufacture or fabrication, or inspections may be made by approved and recognized inspection organizations; provided, no approval shall be based upon reports of such organizations unless the same are in writing and certified by a responsible officer of the organization. All holders of permits, or their agents, shall notify the inspection department and the appropriate inspector at each of the following stages of construction, so that approval may be given before work is continued: 
(1)  Foundation inspection. To be made after trenches are excavated and the necessary reinforcement and forms are in place, and before concrete is placed. Drilled footings, piles and similar types of foundations shall be inspected as installed. 
(2)  Framing inspection. To be made after all structural framing is in place and all roughing in of plumbing, electrical and heating has been installed, after all fire blocking, chimneys, bracing and vents are installed, but before any of the structure is enclosed or covered. Poured-in-place concrete structural elements shall be inspected before each pour of any structural member. 
(3)  Fireproofing inspection. To be made after all areas required to be protected by fireproofing are lathed, but before the plastering or other fireproofing is applied. 
(4)  Final inspection. To be made after building or structure has all doors hung, fixtures set, and is ready for occupancy, but before the building is occupied. 
(b)  Calls for inspection. Requests for inspections may be made to the office of the inspection department or to the appropriate inspector. The inspection department shall make inspections as soon as practicable after request is made therefor, provided the work is ready for inspection at the time the request is made. Reinspections may be made at the convenience of the inspector. No work shall be inspected until it is in proper and completed condition, ready for inspection. All work which has been concealed before the inspection and approval shall be uncovered at the request of the inspector and placed in condition for proper inspection. Approval or rejection of the work shall be furnished by the appropriate inspector in the form of a notice posted on the building or given to the permit holder or his agent. Failure to call for inspections or proceeding without approval at each stage of construction shall be deemed a violation of this chapter. 
(c)  Street or alley lines. Where the applicant for a permit proposes to erect any building or structure on the line of any street, alley or other public place he shall secure a survey of the line of the street, alley or other public place adjacent to the property upon which the building or structure is to be erected before proceeding with construction of the building or structure. It shall be the duty of the building inspector to see that the building does not encroach upon the street or alley or other public place. 
(d)  Certificate of occupancy. No new building or part thereof shall be occupied, and no addition or enlargement of any existing building shall be occupied, and no existing building after being altered or moved shall be occupied, and no change of occupancy shall be made in any existing building or part thereof until the inspection department has issued a certificate of occupancy. A temporary certificate of occupancy may be issued for a portion or portions of a building which may safely be occupied prior to final completion and occupancy of the entire building. A temporary certificate of occupancy shall not be issued, however, until the exterior of the dwelling is completed. Application for a certificate of occupancy may be made by the owner or his agent after all final inspections have been made for new buildings, or, in the case of existing buildings, after supplying the information and data necessary to determine compliance with this chapter, the appropriate regulatory codes and the zoning ordinance for the occupancy intended. The inspection department shall issue a certificate of occupancy when, after examination and inspection, it is found that the building in all respects conforms to the provisions of this chapter, the regulatory codes, and the zoning ordinance for the occupancy intended. 
(Code 1980, § 7-1-25; Res. of 7-13-93) 
Sec. 4-41. - Oversight does not legalize violation. 
    No oversight or dereliction of duty on the part of any inspector or other official or employee of the inspection department shall be deemed to legalize the violation of any provision of this chapter or any provision of any regulatory code herein adopted. 
(Code 1980, § 7-1-26) 
Sec. 4-42. - Powers of inspection officials. 
(a)  Authority. Inspectors are hereby authorized, empowered and directed to enforce all the provisions of this chapter, and the regulatory codes herein adopted. 
(b)  Right of entry. With an appropriate warrant or permission from the owner or occupant, inspectors shall have the right to enter on any premises within the jurisdiction of the regulatory codes herein adopted at reasonable hours for the purpose of inspection or enforcement of the requirements of this chapter and the applicable regulatory codes. 
(c)  Stop orders. Whenever any building or structure or part thereof is being demolished, constructed, reconstructed, altered or repaired in a hazardous manner, or in violation of any provision of this chapter or any other city ordinance, or in violation of any provision of any regulatory code herein adopted, or in violation of the terms of the permit or permits issued therefor, or in such manner as to endanger life or property, the appropriate inspector may order the work to be immediately stopped. The order shall be in writing to the owner of the property or to his agent, or to the person doing the work, and shall state the reasons therefor and the conditions under which the work may be resumed. 
(Code 1980, § 7-1-27) 
Secs. 4-43-4-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PERMITS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Permits required for construction of sidewalks, § 13-61. 
State Law reference- Building permit requirements, G.S. 160A-417 et seq. 

Sec. 4-56. - Required. 
(a)  Building permit. No person shall commence or proceed with the construction, reconstruction, alteration, repair, removal, or demolition of any building or other structure (including lake docks), abutment/bulkhead/retaining wall or any part thereof, without securing a written permit from the building inspector, unless exempted by North Carolina General Statute 160A-417. County board of health approval of a septic tank is required where the sewer system cannot be connected to the city sewer system or where a sewer system is not available. 
(b)  Plumbing permit. No person shall commence or proceed with the installation, extension, or general repair of any plumbing system without a written permit therefor from the plumbing inspector; provided, however, no permit shall be required for minor repairs or replacements on the house side of a trap to an installed system of plumbing if the repairs or replacements do not disrupt the original water supply or the waste or ventilating systems. 
(c)  Heating and air conditioning permit. No person shall commence or proceed with the installation, extension, alteration or general repair of any heating or cooling equipment system without a written permit from the heating and air conditioning inspector; provided, however, no permit shall be required for minor repairs, minor burner services or filter replacements of warm air furnaces or cooling systems. 
(d)  Electrical permit. No person shall commence or proceed with the installation, extension, alteration or general repair of any electrical wiring, devices, appliances or equipment without a written permit therefor from the electrical inspector; provided, however, no permit shall be required for minor repair work such as the replacement of lamps or the connection of portable devices to suitable receptacles which have been permanently installed. No permit shall be required for the installation, alteration or repair of the electrical wiring, devices, appliances and equipment installed by or for an electrical public utility corporation for the use of the corporation in the generation, transmission, distribution, or metering of electrical energy. 
(e)  Lot/landscape clearing. Shall be in accordance with the city's tree ordinance located in chapter 8, section 8-5.1 of the Code of Ordinances. 
(f)  Silt screen required. A silt screen or other approved type of debris barrier shall be in place prior to any soil disturbing activity on any lot or parcel of land. That such screen or barrier shall remain in place during the lot/parcel clearing and during the building construction process. That this section shall also apply to all persons wishing to make improvements to their properties which would result in soil or debris being introduced into any lake within the city. 
(g)  Dock permit. 
(1)  Prior to construction, the appropriate forms (any drawings, site plans, etc.) are submitted to the building inspector. A building permit must be obtained from the building inspector. A fee will be required, set by the board of commissioners, upon recommendation by the city manager. Review and approval must occur before any change or construction can occur. 
(2)  A review by the building inspector is required prior to any action or construction taken by the property owner. Owner shall provide details of dock or pier anchoring system to shore and provide a picture, drawing or other description indicating the colors and materials and sample construction plans showing by notes or detail, all of the structural elements of the structure, including piling embedment, beam sizes, framing, and strapping details. 
(3)  There will be an inspection of all docks on city-owned lakes, once every two (2) years, to ascertain condition, maintenance, esthetics and type of dock. There will be no fee for the inspection, however since docks are located on city-owned property (the lakes), if condition warrants, owner of the dock can be requested to tear down [the dock] and the debris carted away at the owner's expense if the building inspector deems this necessary. A reasonable amount of time will be given if this action is required, however this section authorizes fines, set by the board of commissioners, upon recommendation by the city manager, and shall be levied on a per diem basis due to non-compliance. 
(4)  The following guidelines apply: 
a.  The building inspector shall review all boat dock facilities, to maintain control over boat dock installations to provide for commonality of size, shape, color, and to preserve the access, safe use and enjoyment of the lake. 
b.  Property lines and side set back lines extend into the lake and must be maintained so as not to obstruct access from adjoining properties. See drawing on application form. 
c.  Boat dock facilities length. See section 17-109. 
d.  All dock facilities may be securely and safely anchored to the shore area. Responsibility for safety issues and structural soundness of approved boat dock facilities shall rest entirely with the property owner. 
e.  All dock facilities must be secured to a boat dock or to the shoreline area. Mooring is prohibited. Plastic drums, Styrofoam or similar flotation materials shall provide buoyancy for all floating boat dock facilities. Steel drums are prohibited as well as plastic or composite drums that have contained toxic materials. 
f.  All boat dock facilities will be similar design or construction. No structural walls or roofs are allowed on docks and piers. A skirt around the perimeter should be included to hide the flotation system and structural framing. Tailings are permitted provided they are primarily for safety. 
g.  Products treated with creosotes are prohibited. Consideration should be given to the new composites, plastics, and other products, which are less harmful to the lake environment. 
h.  Conservation and preservation of the natural shoreline will be an essential part of the approval process. Dock facilities may adversely impact near-shore shrubs and vegetation on any lake, which in turn negatively affects near-shore habitats for fish and wildlife. Additionally, placement of docks and removal or thinning of near-shore vegetation may negatively affect aesthetics values of these areas. 
(h)  Driveway permits. No person shall commence or proceed with the installation of a driveway connected to the city street system without a permit which shall be issued at the city hall; and no driveway shall be connected to the state department of transportation road system without a permit from the state department of transportation regional office. Detailed plans and specifications with reference to location of where the driveway will connect to the city street system must accompany each application for a driveway permit. Refer to section 13-36, driveway connections, in the Code of Ordinances for the City of Boiling Spring Lakes for what is applicable for driveway connections approved for driveways abutting city-owned streets. 
(Code 1980, § 7-1-41; Res. of 10-6-98, § 1; Res. of 6-8-99, § 1; Ord. No. 01-08-02, 10-1-02; Ord. No. 08-1-03, 4-1-03; Res. No. 06-09, 4-4-06; Res. No. 2008-24, 7-1-08) 
Sec. 4-57. - Application. 
    Written application shall be made for all permits required by this chapter and shall be made on forms provided by the inspection department. The application shall be made by the owner of the building or structure affected or by his authorized agent or representative and, in addition to such other information as may be required by the appropriate inspector to enable him to determine whether the permit applied for should be issued, shall show the following: 
(1)  Name, residence and business address of owner; 
(2)  Name, residence and business of authorized representative or agent, if any; 
(3)  Name and address of the contractor, if any, together with evidence that he has obtained a certificate from the appropriate state licensing board for such contractors, if a certificate is required for the work involved in the permit for which application is made; 
(4)  Cost of structure to be built. 
(Code 1980, § 7-1-42) 
Sec. 4-58. - Plans and specifications. 
    Detailed plans and specifications shall accompany each application as required by North Carolina General Statute 160A-417 or the city building inspector where plans and specifications are deemed necessary in order to determine whether the proposed work complies with the North Carolina Building Code as amended and any other appropriate regulatory code(s). Plans shall be drawn to scale with sufficient clarity to indicate the nature and extent of the work proposed and shall contain information sufficient to indicate that the work will conform to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1980, § 7-1-43; Res. No. 2008-24, 7-1-08) 
Sec. 4-59. - Limitations on issuance. 
(a)  No building permit shall be issued for any building or structure the estimated total cost of which is more than thirty thousand dollars ($30,000.00), unless the work is to be performed by a licensed general contractor. 
(b)  No building permit shall be issued for any building or structure, other than a one- or two-family dwelling the estimated total cost of which is more than ninety thousand dollars ($90,000.00), unless the plans bear the state seal of a registered architect or a registered engineer. 
(c)  Where any provisions of the General Statutes or of any ordinance require that work be done by a licensed specialty contractor of any kind, no permit for the work shall be issued unless it is to be performed by the licensed specialty contractor. 
(d)  Where detailed plans and specifications are required by this chapter, no building permit shall be issued unless the plans and specifications have been provided. 
(e)  A recent lot survey (less than one (1) year old) is required plus a verification by a surveyor that the building is properly located on the lot with respect to set back requirements. 
(Code 1980, § 7-1-44; Res. of 7-11-95; Ord. No. 01-08-02, 10-1-02) 
Sec. 4-60. - Issuance of permit. 
(a)  When proper application for a permit has been made, and the appropriate inspector is satisfied that the application and the proposed work comply with the provisions of this chapter and the appropriate regulatory codes, he shall issue the permit, upon payment of the proper fee or fees as hereinafter provided. 
(b)  Prior to commencement of any construction, the building permit shall be prominently posted on a pole or stake on the building lot in such a manner as to be visible from the street abutting such lot and it shall remain in such position until a certificate of occupancy has been issued by the building inspector. 
(Code 1980, § 7-1-45) 
Sec. 4-61. - Revocation. 
    The appropriate inspector may revoke and require the return of any permit by notifying the permit holder in writing, stating the reason for the revocation. Permits shall be revoked for any material departure from the approved application, plans or specifications; for refusal or failure to comply with proper orders of the inspector; for refusal or failure to comply with requirements of this chapter and the appropriate regulatory codes; or for false statements or misrepresentations made in securing the permit. 
(Code 1980, § 7-1-46) 
Sec. 4-62. - Time limitations on validity. 
    All permits issued under this chapter shall expire by limitation six (6) months after the date of issuance if the work authorized by the permit has not been commenced. If after commencement the work is discontinued for a period of twelve (12) months, the permit therefor shall immediately expire. No work authorized by any permit which has expired shall thereafter be performed until a new permit has been secured. 
(Code 1980, § 7-1-47) 
Sec. 4-63. - Changes in work after issuance. 
    After a permit has been issued, changes or deviations from the terms of the application and permit, or changes or deviations from the plans or specifications involving any work under the jurisdiction of this chapter or of any regulatory code adopted herein, shall not be made until specific written approval of the changes or deviations has been obtained from the appropriate inspector. 
(Code 1980, § 7-1-48) 
Sec. 4-64. - Fees. 
    Fees for permits shall be based upon the total estimated cost of the proposed work, including all subcontracts, if any, but in no case shall the total estimated cost be less than the market value of similar completed work in the city as determined by the appropriate inspector or inspectors. The building inspector shall recommend the fees and fees will be approved by the board of commissioners. Building permit fees shall be published in the fee schedule adopted by the board of commissioners and modified from time to time. 
(Code 1980, § 7-1-49; Res. No. 2008-24, 7-1-08) 
Sec. 4-65. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Res. No. 2008-24, effective July 1, 2008, repealed § 4-66 in its entirety. Former section pertained to bond required prior to construction et seq. See Code Comparative Table. 
Sec. 4-66. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Res. No. 2008-24, effective July 1, 2008, repealed § 4-65 in its entirety. Former section pertained to bonds for construction, removal, demolition of building. See Code Comparative Table. 
Sec. 4-67. - Job site litter. 
(a)  To control litter generated by construction, all job sites must have a container, either a dumpster or a fabricated container approved by the building inspector, for the purpose of holding litter and construction waste until same can be removed from the job site and disposed of properly. 
(b)  Failure to provide an approved container will result in a stop work order being issued. 
(Res. of 6-8-99, § 2; Ord. No. 01-08-02, 10-1-02) 
Secs. 4-68-4-75. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - BUILDING, PLUMBING, ELECTRICAL, HEATING AND AIR CONDITIONING CONTRACTOR LICENSES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses and business regulations, Ch. 7. 
State Law reference- Electrical contractors, G.S. 87-39 et seq.; statewide license tax for electricians, G.S. 105-91. 

Sec. 4-76. - Licensing required; cost. 
    Every person carrying on the business of building contractor, plumbing contractor, heating and air conditioning contractor or electrical contractor within the city shall be required to purchase a city privilege license in accordance with chapter 7 section 7-41 of the Code of Ordinances. Applicants for a license must be licensed by the state in their specialty trade or business, and the state license must be presented prior to being issued a city privilege license. If the owner of any proposed one-or two-family building certifies that he or she will act in the capacity of general contractor for the building, he or she need not be licensed as set forth above unless provided in the codes set forth in article III. However, licensed personnel must perform any specialty work set forth above (plumbing, heating and air conditioning and electrical). 
(Code 1980, § 7-1-51; Ord. No. 01-08-02, 10-1-02; Res. No. 2008-24, 7-1-08) 
Sec. 4-77. - Responsibility for damages to streets. 
    Each building contractor, including the owner of a building wherein the owner is acting as his own general building contractor, shall be responsible and liable for any damages which may occur to the city streets and drainage systems as a direct result of any work he may perform in constructing buildings. The building inspector shall notify the street foreman in all cases wherein damages have occurred as a result of any actions on the part of the building contractor. Based on the estimate of such damages by the street foreman, the building contractor shall be submitted a bill by the city clerk for the damages. Failure to reimburse the city for such damages shall be adequate grounds for revoking the building contractor's city privilege license. 
(Code 1980, § 7-1-52) 
Sec. 4-78. - Road license fee. 
    Each building contractor or owner of a new residential dwelling unit or new commercial building that is being constructed adjacent to or contiguous to a city maintained street, or contractor or owner who is arranging for the placement of a manufactured or mobile home that is on a lot adjacent to or contiguous to a city maintained street shall pay a non-refundable street license fee. The license fee will be published in the city's schedule of fees as established by the board of commissioners and modified from time to time. 
    Said funds shall be deposited into the general fund and dedicated for street maintenance. Road damage in excess of the published amount at any site shall be collected in accordance with section 4-77 of the Code of Ordinances. 
(Res. No. 05-28, § 1, 12-6-05; Res. No. 06-19, § 1, 5-19-06; Res. No. 2008-24, 7-1-08; Ord. No. 2017-01, § 1, 3-7-17) 
Sec. 4-79. - Gutters, downspouts, drainage required. 
    Every home constructed within the City of Boiling Spring Lakes shall be equipped with gutters and downspouts, or other appropriate devices, that shall result in the discharge of rain water from each downspout into a three (3) foot square by two (2) foot deep pit filled with #57 stone.
