(4)  On private property without the consent of the owner, occupant or lessee thereof for longer than two (2) hours. 
    Derelict vehicle means a motor vehicle: 
(1)  Whose certificate of registration has expired and/or the registered owner no longer resides at the address listed on the last certificate of registration on record with the North Carolina Department of Transportation. 
(2)  Whose major parts have been removed so as to render the vehicle inoperable and incapable of passing inspection as required under existing standards; 
(3)  Whose manufacturer's serial plates, vehicle identification numbers, license number plates and any other means of identification have been removed so as to nullify efforts to locate or identify the registered and legal owner; 
(4)  Whose registered and legal owner of record disclaims ownership or releases his rights thereto. 
(5)  Any derelict vehicle includes but not limited to any motor vehicle, truck, bus, trailer or any unit which is driven or pushed and/or powered by internal combustion engine or electric power. 
(6)  A vehicle that does not display a current state inspection sticker as required by the State of North Carolina. 
    Junked motor vehicle. A junked motor vehicle is an abandoned motor vehicle that also: 
(1)  Is partially dismantled or wrecked; 
(2)  Cannot be self-propelled or moved in the manner in which it was originally intended to move; 
(3)  Is more than five (5) years old and worth less than one hundred dollars ($100.00); or 
(4)  Does not display a current license plate. 
(5)  A vehicle that does not display a current state inspection sticker as required by the State of North Carolina. 
(Code 1980, § 6-2-1; Res. of 5-4-94; Res. of 3-7-00; Res. of 10-3-00, §§ 1, 2) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.S. 20-137.7, 160A-303. 
Sec. 9-32. - Purpose. 
    Abandoned, junked and derelict motor vehicles constitute a hazard to the health and welfare of the people of the city in that such vehicles can harbor noxious diseases, furnish shelter and breeding places for vermin, and present physical dangers to the safety and well-being of children and other citizens. It is therefore in the public interest that the accumulation of abandoned, junked and derelict motor vehicles be eliminated and that the abandonment of such vehicles be prevented. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.S. 20-137.6. 
Sec. 9-33. - Exempt vehicles. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to vehicles located on used car lots, in private garages, enclosed parking lots, or on any other parking area on private property which is not visible from any public street or highway, nor to motor vehicles classified as antiques and registered under the laws of the state, those not required by law to be registered, or those in possession of a salvage yard as defined in G.S. 20-137.7, unless that vehicle presents some safety or health hazard or constitutes a nuisance. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.S. 20-137.14, 160A-303(g). 
Sec. 9-34. - Duty of owner to remove. 
    It shall be the duty and responsibility of the owner of an abandoned, junked or derelict motor vehicle to cause the removal thereof immediately and to pay all costs incident to the removal. It shall be unlawful for any person to allow an abandoned, junked or derelict motor vehicle owned by him to remain on a public street, highway and private property after notice has been duly given pursuant to section 9-35 to the person to have the vehicle removed. 
(Code 1980, § 6-2-3; Res. of 3-7-00) 
Sec. 9-35. - Notice. 
(a)  When any vehicle is derelict, junked or abandoned in this city, a tag in the form which is on file in the city code enforcement officer's office shall be placed on the vehicle which shall state and shall be notice to the owner, the person in possession of the vehicle or any lienholder that the vehicle is considered to have been derelict, junked or abandoned and is subject to forfeiture to the city. 
(b)  The tag shall state and shall serve as the only notice that if the vehicle is not removed within five (5) days from the date reflected on the tag, it will be removed to the place designated to be sold. After the vehicle is removed, the city shall give notice in writing to the person in whose name the vehicle was last registered at the last address reflected in the state department of transportation records and to any lienholder of record that the vehicle is being held due to the violation of this article, designating the place where the vehicle is being held, and that if it is not redeemed within ten (10) days from the date of the notice by paying all costs of removal and storage the vehicle shall be sold pursuant to section 9-38. The proceeds of the sale shall be deposited in the fund established for the purpose and held pursuant to section 9-38. 
(c)  If the value of the vehicle is determined to be more than one hundred dollars ($100.00), and if the identity of the last registered owner cannot be determined or if the registration contains no address for the owner, or if it is impossible to determine with reasonable certainty the identification and addresses of any lienholders, notice by one (1) publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the area where the vehicle was located shall be sufficient to meet all requirements of notice pursuant to this section. The notice of publication may contain multiple listings of vehicles. Five (5) days after date of publication the advertised vehicles may be processed pursuant to section 9-38. The proceeds of the sale shall be deposited in the fund established for the purpose of administering the provisions of this section. 
(d)  If the value of the vehicle is determined to be less than one hundred dollars ($100.00), and if the identity of the last registered owner cannot be determined or if the registration contains no address for the owner, or if it is impossible to determine with reasonable certainty the identification and addresses of any lienholders, no notice in addition to that required by subsection (a) hereof shall be required prior to sale. 
(e)  All the law enforcement and code enforcement officers of the city are given the authority to appraise or determine the value of derelict, junked or abandoned vehicles as defined in this article. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.S. 20-137.10. 
(Res. of 3-7-00; Ord. No. 01-08-02, 10-1-02) 
Sec. 9-36. - Removal by city. 
    An abandoned, junked or derelict motor vehicle on a public street or highway or on property owned or operated by the city or on private property may be removed by or under the direction of the chief of police to the storage garage, but no vehicle shall be removed from private property without the written request or permission of the owner, lessee or occupant thereof unless the vehicle has been declared by the board of commissioners or a duly authorized officer or employee after notice pursuant to section 9-35 to be a health or safety hazard. 
(Code 1980, § 6-2-4; Ord. No. 01-08-02, 10-1-02) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.S. 160A-303(c). 
Sec. 9-37. - Responsibility for costs of removal. 
(a)  When an abandoned, derelict or junked motor vehicle is removed from private property at the request of the owner, lessee or occupant thereof, the person at whose request the vehicle is removed shall be responsible for and may be required to pay or otherwise indemnify the city against any loss, expense or liability incurred because of the removal, storage or sale of the abandoned, derelict or junked vehicle. 
(b)  Reserved. 
(Code 1980, § 6-2-5; Ord. No. 01-08-02, 10-1-02) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.S. 160A-303(e). 
Sec. 9-38. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 01-08-02, adopted October 1, 2002, repealed § 9-38 in its entirety. Formerly said section pertained to enforcement by sale. 
Sec. 9-39. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 01-08-02, adopted October 1, 2002, repealed § 9-39 in its entirety. Formerly said section pertained to notice and hearings. 
Sec. 9-40. - No liability for removal. 
    No agent or employee of the city, no person or occupant of the premises from which any junked, derelict or abandoned vehicle shall be removed, nor any person or firm contracting for the removal of or disposition of any such vehicle shall be held criminally or civilly liable in any way arising out of or caused by carrying out or enforcing any provisions of this article. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.S. 20-137.13, 160A-303(f). 
Secs. 9-41-9-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LITTER[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and certain other public places, Ch. 13. 

Sec. 9-61. - Prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to throw or deposit upon any street or sidewalk, or upon any private property, except with written permission of the owner or occupant of the private property, any trash, refuse, garbage, building material, cans, bottles, broken glass, paper or any type of litter. 
(Code 1980, § 6-4-1) 
Sec. 9-62. - Littering from vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person while a driver or a passenger in a vehicle to throw or deposit litter upon any street or other public place within the city, or upon private property. 
    All debris that is hauled within the city limits shall be covered by a tarpaulin such that it will not blow from or fall from the vehicle within which it is being transported. 
(Code 1980, § 6-4-2; Res. No. 05-14, § 1, 6-7-05) 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, Ch. 15; lakes advisory board to recommend regulations for the use and maintenance of all lakes, § 2-111 et seq. 
Sec. 9-63. - Maintenance of public areas. 
    Every owner, lessee, tenant, occupant or other person in charge of any commercial establishment or premises which maintains any paved or unpaved areas for the use of the public, either for parking or as access areas and incident to the carrying on of the principal business of any commercial establishment or premises and which parking or access areas abut or lie within ten (10) feet of any public street or other public way, shall keep and maintain the areas clean and free from trash, litter, rubbish and any materials liable to be blown, deposited or cast upon the street or other public way. 
(Code 1980, § 6-4-3) 
Sec. 9-64. - Furnishing of receptacles. 
    Suitable receptacles may be provided in parking or access areas within the meaning of section 9-63. The receptacles shall be plainly marked and constructed to prevent scattering of any trash, litter, rubbish or other materials deposited therein. 
(Code 1980, § 6-4-4) 
Sec. 9-65. - Penalty. 
    Violation of this section may subject the offender to penalties or fines. The civil penalties have been established to cover the cost of enforcement of this section in accordance with section 1-15 of this Code. The civil penalty shall be as published in the fee schedule adopted by the board of commissioners and modified from time to time. If appropriate, the offender shall also be responsible for the cost to repair or replace any damaged property that may be incurred as a result of a violation of this article. 
(Code 1980, § 6-4-5; Res. of 4-6-93; Res. of 11-14-95; Res. No. 2008-24, 7-1-08) 
Secs. 9-66-9-85. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - NOISE[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Res. No. 2014-08, adopted Dec. 2, 2014, repealed former art. IV in its entirety and enacted new provisions as herein set out. Former art. IV, §§ 9-86-9-90 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Res. No. 2001-21, § 1, adopted Oct. 15, 2001; Res. No. 2008-24, adopted July 1, 2008; and Ord. No. 2009-42, adopted Oct. 6, 2009. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate noise, G.S. 160A-184. 

Sec. 9-86. - Definitions. 
    The following words and terms, when used in this article, shall have the following meanings unless the context clearly indicates otherwise. 
    Animal means any living creature, domestic or wild. 
    Construction means any site preparation, assembly, erection, repair, alteration or similar action including demolition of buildings or structures. 
    Demolition means any dismantling, destruction or removal of buildings, structures or roadways. 
    Emergency work means any work or action necessary to deliver essential public services including, but not limited to, repairing water, gas, electricity, telephone, sewer, or public transportation facilities, removing fallen trees on public right-of-way or abating life threatening conditions. 
    Enforcement officer means city police officer or city zoning official. 
    Impulsive sound means either a single pressure peak or a single burst (multiple pressure peaks) that has a duration of less than one (1) second. 
    Motor vehicle means any vehicle that is propelled other than by human or animal power on land. 
    Muffler means a properly functioning sound dissipation device or system for abating the sound of escaping gases on equipment where such a device is part of the normal configuration of the equipment. 
    Multi-dwelling unit building means any building comprising two (2) or more dwelling units. That this is including, but not limited to apartments, condominiums, co-ops, multiple-family houses, townhouses and attached residences. 
    Multi-use property means any distinct parcel of land that is used for more than one (1) category of activity. Examples include, but are not limited to: 
(1)  A commercial, residential or public service property having boilers, incinerators, elevators, automatic garage doors, air conditioners, laundry rooms, utility provisions, or health and recreational facilities, or other similar devises or areas, either in the interior or on the exterior of the building, which may be a source of elevated sound levels at another category on the same distinct parcel of land. 
(2)  A building which is both commercial (usually on the ground floor and residential property located above, behind, below or adjacent. 
    Plainly audible means any sound that can be detected by a person using his or her unaided hearing facilities. 
    Public right-of-way means any street, avenue, boulevard, road, highway, sidewalk, alley or easement that is owned leased or controlled by a government entity. 
    Public space means any real property or structures thereon that are owned, leased, or controlled by a government agency. 
    Real property line means either (a) the imaginary line, including its vertical extension that separates one (1) parcel of real property from another; (b) the vertical and horizontal boundaries of a dwelling unit that is part of a multi-dwelling building, or (c) on a multi-use property, the interface between the two (2) portions of the property on which different categories of activity are being performed (e.g. if the multi-use property is a building which is residential upstairs and commercial downstairs, then the real property line would be the interface between the residential area and the commercial area. 
(Res. No. 2014-08, 12-2-14) 
Sec. 9-87. - Applicability. 
(a)  This noise article applies to sound from the following property categories: 
(1)  Industrial facilities; 
(2)  Commercial facilities; 
(3)  Public service facilities; 
(4)  Community service facilities; 
(5)  Residential properties; 
(6)  Multi-use properties; 
(7)  Public and private rights-of-way; 
(8)  Public spaces; 
(9)  Multi-dwelling unit buildings. 
(b)  This noise article applies to sound received at the following property categories: 
(1)  Commercial facilities; 
(2)  Public service facilities; 
(3)  Community service facilities; 
(4)  Residential properties; 
(5)  Multi-use properties; 
(6)  Multi-dwelling unit buildings. 
(c)  The following shall be exempted from this article: 
(1)  Occasional firing of ceremonial cannons. 
(Res. No. 2014-08, 12-2-14) 
Sec. 9-88. - Enforcement officer(s). 
    All enforcement officers shall have the power to: 
(1)  Coordinate the noise control activities of all departments in the City of Boiling Spring Lakes, North Carolina, and cooperate with all other public bodies and agencies to the extent practicable; 
(2)  Review public and private projects, subject to mandatory review or approval by other departments or boards, for compliance with this article. 
(Res. No. 2014-08, 12-2-14) 
Sec. 9-89. - Unnecessary noise prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to create or assist in creating any unreasonably loud, disturbing sounds levels in the city taking into consideration volume, duration, frequency and other characteristics of the sound. 
(Res. No. 2014-08, 12-2-14) 
Sec. 9-90. - Certain noises expressly prohibited. 
    The following acts or activities, among others, are hereby declared to be unreasonably loud, disturbing sound levels, in violation of this section, but the enumeration shall not be deemed to be exclusive: 
(1)  The sounding of any horn or signal device on any automobile, motorcycle, bus or other vehicle while not in motion, except as a danger signal if another vehicle is approaching apparently out of control, or if in motion only as a danger signal after or as brakes are being applied and deceleration of the vehicle is intended; the creation by means of any such horn or signal device of any unreasonably loud, disturbing sound level; and the sounding of the device for any unreasonable period of time; 
(2)  The sounding of any gong, bell or siren such that a reasonably prudent person would recognize as likely to unreasonably disturb persons in the vicinity, except for the use of a gong or siren upon a police, fire or other emergency vehicle or by a church or school; 
(3)  The playing, use or operation of any radio, musical instrument, electronic sound amplification equipment or other similar device in such manner or with the volume so that a reasonably prudent person would recognize as likely to unreasonably disturb persons in the vicinity, except with an appropriate permit; 
(4)  The keeping of any animal or bird which makes frequent or long continued sounds such that a reasonably prudent person would recognize as likely to unreasonably disturb persons in the vicinity; 
(5)  The use of any automobile, motorcycle or other vehicle so out of repair, so loaded or in a manner as to create unreasonably loud, disturbing sounds; 
(6)  The discharge into the open air of the exhaust from any steam engine, stationary internal combustion engine, motor vehicle, except through a muffler or other device which will prevent unreasonably loud, disturbing sounds therefrom; 
(7)  The use of any mechanical device operated by compressed air unless the sound created thereby is effectively muffled and reduced; 
(8)  The erection, construction (including excavation), demolition, alteration or repair of any building or structure in a residential or business district other than between the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m.; 
(9)  The creation of unreasonably loud, disturbing sound levels adjacent to any school, educational facility, church or court during normal operating hours, or within one hundred fifty (150) feet of any hospital, which a reasonably prudent person would recognize as likely to unreasonably interfere with the working of the institutions; provided conspicuous signs are displayed indicating that such area is a school, educational facility, church, court or hospital area; 
(10)  The operating or maintaining of any garage or service station in any residential area so as to cause unreasonably loud, disturbing sounds to be emitted between the hours of 9:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. on any day; 
(11)  The use of any electronic sound amplification equipment for advertising or solicitation purposes, except with an appropriate permit; 
(12)  The shouting or using any drum, loud speaker or other instrument or device for the purpose of attracting attention to any performance, show or sale or display of merchandise, except with an appropriate permit; and 
(13)  The firing or discharging of firecrackers, gunpowder or any other combustible substance such that a reasonably prudent person would recognize is likely to unreasonably disturb persons in the vicinity. 
(Res. No. 2014-08, 12-2-14) 
Sec. 9-91. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Violations of any provisions of this article shall be a cause for a city citation to be issued to the violator by the "enforcement officers." 
(b)  Violation of this section may subject the offender to civil penalties that have been established to cover the cost of enforcement of this section in accordance with section 1-15 of this Code. The civil penalty shall be as published in the fee schedule adopted by the board of commissioners and modified from time to time. 
(c)  No provision of this article shall be construed to impair any common law or statutory cause of action, or legal remedy therefrom, of any person or injury or damage arising from any violation of this article or from other law. 
(Res. No. 2014-08, 12-2-14) 
Sec. 9-92. - Permits. 
(a)  Any person wishing to engage in activities regulated by this chapter may do so when a specific permit is approved by the city manager or his or her designee. Applications shall be submitted on forms supplied by the city. The permit shall not be unreasonably withheld and may contain appropriate conditions, including maximum decibel levels, designed to minimize the disruptive impact. Permits for activities which are significantly for religious or political purposes shall be granted, subject only to reasonable time, place and manner restrictions. Permits issued under this section may specify that the permission granted will continue for a stated period of time or until revoked. Any permit may be revoked if it is determined that the authorized activity has resulted in generation of unreasonably loud disturbing sound levels. 
(b)  In case an application is denied, a permit is approved with conditions unacceptable to the applicant or a permit is revoked, the applicant may appeal to the board of commissioners, for appropriate relief, by written request 
(Res. No. 2014-08, 12-2-14) 
Secs. 9-93-9-115. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - WEEDS AND WILD GROWTH[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Abatement of public health nuisances, G.S. 160A-193. 

Sec. 9-116. - Control of weeds, grass, other vegetation near streets, other public ways. 
    No person having control of any improved lot or any part thereof in the city shall permit or maintain on any such lot, or on or along the sidewalk or street adjacent to the same between the property line and the curb or middle of the alley or for ten (10) feet outside the property line if there is no curb, any growth of weeds, grass or other rank vegetation to a height greater than ten (10) inches, or any accumulation of dead weeds, grass or brush. No person shall cause, suffer or allow poison ivy, ragweed or other poisonous or detrimental plants to grow on any such lot or land so that any part of such ivy, ragweed, or other poisonous or harmful weed shall extend upon, cover, overhang or border any public place or allow seed, pollen or other poisonous particles or emanations therefrom to be carried through the air into any public place. 
(Code 1980, § 6-3-1) 
Sec. 9-117. - Cutting of vegetation required. 
    Every person owning or occupying any lot shall cut or cause to be cut and removed all weeds, grass or other rank, poisonous or harmful vegetation as often as may be necessary to comply with the provisions of this article, provided that cutting and removing such weeds, grass and vegetation shall be done at least twice annually, with the first cutting to be done before June 15 and the second cutting to be done before August 15 each year. 
(Code 1980, § 6-3-2) 
Sec. 9-118. - Notice of violation; removal by city. 
(a)  If the provisions of this article are not complied with, the city clerk shall serve written notice upon the owner, lessee or occupant or any person having the care or control of any such lot to comply with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  If the person upon whom the notice is served fails, neglects or refuses to cut and remove or to cause to be cut and removed such weeds, grass or other vegetation within ten (10) days after receiving such notice or if the owner or his representative cannot be found in the city, the clerk shall cause such weeds, grass and other vegetation to be cut and removed. 
(Code 1980, § 6-3-3) 
Sec. 9-119. - Assessment of cost of removal. 
    The actual cost of cutting and removing unlawful weeds, grass or other vegetation by the city, plus five (5) percent for inspection and additional costs in connection therewith, shall be certified by the city clerk to be a lien upon the property upon which such weeds, grass and other vegetation were located. Such cost shall be added to the taxes next to be assessed and levied upon such lot, shall bear interest at the same rate as taxes and shall be collected and enforced by the same officer and in the same manner as taxes. 
(Code 1980, § 6-3-4) 
Sec. 9-120. - Refusal or failure to comply; obstructing city officials. 
    No person shall neglect to cut and remove weeds, grass or other vegetation as directed in this article, nor fail, neglect or refuse to comply with the provisions of any notice herein provided, nor resist or obstruct the clerk or his agents in the cutting and removal of weeds, grass and other vegetation. 
(Code 1980, § 6-3-5) 
Secs. 9-121-9-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - FALSE ALARM PREVENTION[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Res. No. 2002-23, §§ 1-7, adopted Aug. 6, 2002, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, inclusion as Art. VI, §§ 9-131-9-137 was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 9-131. - Purpose. 
(a)  The purpose of this article is to encourage alarm users and alarm companies to maintain the operational reliability of alarm systems and to properly use alarm system[s] in order to reduce or eliminate false/accidental alarm dispatches of fire apparatus or police units. 
(b)  This article governs systems intended to summon fire or police response, establish a fee associated with penalties for violations. 
(Res. No. 2002-23, § 1, 8-6-02) 
Sec. 9-132. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. 
    Alarm business means the business by any individual, partnership or corporation serving, repairing, altering, replacing, moving or installing any alarm system, or causing to be sold, leased, maintained, serviced, repaired, altered, replaced, moved or installed any alarm system in or on any commercial or residential building, structure or premises, and shall not include any other activity of the business 
    Alarm dispatch request means a notification to the public safety officials by an alarm company that an alarm has been activated at an alarm site. 
    Alarm installation means any alarm device or combination of devices installed for one (1) or more commercial or residential buildings, structures or premises. 
    Alarm system means a device or series of devices, including but not limited to, systems interconnected with a radio frequency signal, which are designed to warn of fire or breaking and entering, transmitting a remote or local audible, visual, or electronic signal indicating an alarm condition that may require attention by a fire or police department. 
    Automatic telephone dialing device or digital alarm communications system means an alarm system that automatically sends a prerecorded voice message or coded signal over regular telephone lines by direct connection or any other digital method indicating the existence of the emergency situation that the alarm system is designed to detect. 
    Alarm means the activation of an alarm signal that produced either an audible sound that can be heard from the interior or exterior of a commercial or residential building, structure or premise housing the alarm system, or the emission of a signal to a direct monitoring service which in turn notifies the Brunswick County Communications Center or directly notifies local officials that an alarm has been activated. 
    False fire alarm means any transmitted alarm signal in which there is no sign of smoke, fire, [or] water flow conditions. 
    False burglary alarm means any transmitted alarm signal in which there is no sign of an attempted or actually breaking and entering. 
(Res. No. 2002-23, § 2, 8-6-02) 
Sec. 9-133. - General regulations. 
(a)  The alarm user shall maintain the premises and the alarm system in a manner that will minimize or eliminate false/accidental alarm dispatches and activate the alarm code only for the occurrence of events it was designed to report. 
(b)  The alarm user shall respond or cause a responsible representative to respond to the alarm site within thirty (30) minutes when notified by officials. 
(c)  Each alarm user shall furnish the City of Boiling Spring Lakes Police Department, in writing, the name and telephone numbers of at least one (1), but no more than five (5), persons authorized and able to deactivate the alarm system. 
(d)  The alarm user shall adjust the mechanism or cause the mechanism to be adjusted so that an alarm signal on the exterior of the alarm site shall sound not longer than fifteen (15) minutes, requiring an automatic reset. 
(Res. No. 2002-23, § 3, 8-6-02) 
Sec. 9-134. - Alarm response. 
(a)  Violation of this section may subject the offender to civil penalties that have been established to cover the cost of enforcement of this section in accordance with section 1-15 of this Code. The civil penalty shall be as published in the fee schedule adopted by the board of commissioners and modified from time to time. 
(b)  No fee shall be assessed if the false/accidental alarm dispatch is: 
(1)  Caused by a hurricane, tornado or lightening strikes where there is clear evidence of physical damage to the alarm system. 
(2)  Activated by an electrical power outage to the electric meter on the commercial or residential building housing the activated alarm system. 
(3)  An alarm system activated during an alarm system tests conducted by the fire marshal's office or chief of police for the purpose of computing alarm times. 
(c)  No fee shall be assessed if the alarm is caused by: 
(1)  Actual fire. 
(2)  Smoke condition without fire. 
(3)  Sprinkler water flow has tripped system due to sprinkler head activating with or without fire. 
(4)  Attempted or actual breaking and entering. 
(Res. No. 2002-23, § 4, 8-6-02; Res. No. 2008-24, 7-1-08) 
Sec. 9-135. - Prohibited acts. 
    Except as alarm testing provided in section 9-134, it shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly activate an alarm when no fire or breaking and entering exists. 
(Res. No. 2002-23, § 5, 8-6-02) 
Sec. 9-136. - Enforcement of violations. 
(a)  This article shall only apply and be enforced within the incorporated City Limits of Boiling Spring Lakes. The fire department shall submit violations to the police chief within two (2) days of any violation so the police department can follow up with the issuance of a citation. 
(b)  Civil penalties under section 9-134, if not paid within fifteen (15) days of issuance of the citation, may be recovered by the city in a civil action in the nature of a debt. 
(c)  As of the effective date of this article [August 5, 2002], alarm users shall be deemed to have a zero alarm responses for the purposes of section 9-134. 
(Res. No. 2002-23, § 6, 8-6-02; Res. No. 04-30, § 1, 11-3-04) 
Sec. 9-137. - Collected funds. 
    All collected funds shall be placed in the City of Boiling Spring Lakes General Fund. Seventy (70) percent of the funds collected from fire false alarms shall be paid to the Boiling Spring Lakes Volunteer Fire Department. The city shall make said payments to the department on a quarterly basis. 
(Res. No. 2002-23, § 7, 8-6-02; Res. No. 04-31, § 1, 11-3-04) 
Chapter 10 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- An ordinance adopted June 7, 1994, amended former Ch. 10, relative to parks and recreation, in its entirety to read as herein set out. The provisions of former Ch. 10 derived from Code 1980, §§ 3-3-1-3-3-11, 6-6-5; and ordinances adopted Aug. 4, 1986 and Jan. 7, 1992. 
Cross reference- Procedure for disbursement of certain surplus public property, § 5-36 et seq.; streets, sidewalks and certain other public places, Ch. 13. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Park means a park, reservation, playground, community center, recreation center, swimming-boating-fishing area, stadium or any other area or structure in the city, owned or leased or used by the city and devoted to active or passive recreation, wildlife, cultural and aesthetic purposes, including property owned by others and devoted to park purposes under the jurisdiction of the board of commissioners. 
    Vehicle means any wheeled conveyance, whether motor-powered, animal-drawn or self-propelled, except wheelchairs and similar vehicles, baby carriages and vehicles in the service of the city parks. 
    Camping means staying overnight in a tent, trailer, motorized home or sleeping out in sleeping bags. Requires a special use permit, see section 10-52 and Appendix A. 
Editor's note- Appendix A referenced above is not set out in this Code but is on file and available for inspection in the offices of the city. 
    Trailer or motorized home, whether or not self contained, means one not permanently or semi permanently connected to sewer, septic tank, water and utilities. 
(Ord. of 6-7-94; Res. of 8-6-96; Ord. No. 01-08-02, 10-1-02; Ord. No. 06-01-03, 3-4-03) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Secs. 10-2-10-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2. 

Sec. 10-26. - Commissioner for parks and recreation. 
    The city manager shall be responsible for the enforcement of this chapter. 
(Ord. of 6-7-94; Res. of 8-6-96; Ord. No. 06-01-03, 3-4-03) 
Cross reference- Mayor and board of commissioners, § 2-26 et seq. 
Sec. 10-27. - Enforcement. 
(1)  Police officers of the city shall diligently enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
(2)  Police officers shall have the authority to eject from any park, any person acting in violation of this chapter or any section of this Code, or any law of the state. 
(3)  Violation of this section may subject the offender to civil penalties that have been established to cover the cost of enforcement of this section in accordance with section 1-15 of this Code. The civil penalty shall be as published in the fee schedule adopted by the board of commissioners and modified from time to time. If appropriate, the offender shall also be responsible for the cost to repair or replace any damaged property that may be incurred as a result of a violation of this article. 
(Ord. of 6-7-94; Res. of 11-14-95; Res. of 8-6-96; Res. No. 2008-24, 7-1-08) 
Secs. 10-28-10-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PARK REGULATIONS 

Sec. 10-51. - Park operating policy. 
(1)  Only designated and maintained parks shall be open to the public. 
(2)  The hours of operation for all parks, with the exception of North Lake Park, shall be from sunrise to sunset with the exception only for official city sponsored events. 
(3)  The hours of operation for North Lake Park shall be from 5:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m. 
(Ord. of 6-7-94; Res. of 3-9-99, § 1; Res. No. 2008-09, 4-1-08; Ord. No. 2017-03, § 1, 5-2-17) 
Sec. 10-52. - Park reservations.[3] 
    Persons wishing to reserve park space shall file an application for a permit with the parks and recreation department thirty (30) days in advance of the proposed activity. The cost of the permit shall be as published in the fee schedule adopted by the board of commissioners and modified from time to time. 
The proposed activity shall meet the following requirements: 
(1)  The activity shall not interfere with or detract from the public's enjoyment of the park or infringe upon the rights of adjacent property owners. 
(2)  The activity shall not interfere with or detract from the promotion of public health, welfare, safety and recreation. 
(3)  The activity shall not incite violence, crime or disorderly conduct or otherwise create public nuisances. 
(4)  The activity shall not entail extraordinary or burdensome expense or police operation by the city. 
(5)  The activity shall be bound by all park rules and regulations and all applicable ordinances. 
    Within fourteen (14) days after receipt of an application, the parks and recreation director shall advise an applicant in writing of the reasons for refusing a permit, and any aggrieved person shall have the right to appeal in writing within seven (7) days to the city manager who shall consider the application under the requirements set forth herein, and sustain or overrule the decision within seven (7) days. The decision of the city manager shall be final. 
    The chief of police shall have the authority to revoke a permit upon a finding of violation of any rule or ordinance, or upon good cause shown. 
(Ord. of 6-7-94; Ord. No. 06-01-03, 3-4-03; Res. No. 2008-24, 7-1-08) 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2008-24, amended the title of § 10-52 to read as herein set out. Formerly said title pertained to special use permits. 

Sec. 10-53. - Injuring, tampering with buildings, facilities, other property. 
(a)  No person in a park shall willfully mark, deface, disfigure, adulterate, injure, tamper with, displace or remove any buildings, bridges, tables, benches, fireplaces, railings, swimming pools or wading pools, paving or paving material, water lines or other public utilities or parts of appurtenances thereof, fences, signs, notices or placards whether temporary or permanent, receptacles, monuments, stakes, posts or other boundary markers or other structures, improvements or equipment, facilities or park property or appurtenances whatsoever, either real or personal. 
(b)  Skateboards, roller blades or any type or form of skating, or riding bicycles or tricycles on any basketball or tennis court surface shall be prohibited. 
(Ord. of 6-7-94; Res. of 9-5-00, §§ 1, 2) 
Sec. 10-54. - Forced entry into locked restrooms; use of facility designated for opposite sex. 
    No person in a park shall force entry into any restroom or washroom that is locked or bolted; and no person over the age of five (5) years shall use any restroom, washroom or locker room designated for the opposite sex. 
(Ord. of 6-7-94) 
Sec. 10-55. - Digging or removing soil, trees, etc.; excavations. 
    No person in a park shall dig or remove any soil, rocks or stones (except in areas designated for that purpose), or any trees, shrubs, plants, plantings, grass, down-timber or other wood or materials, or make any excavation by tool, equipment, blasting or other means, or agency without permission from the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. of 6-7-94) 
Sec. 10-56. - Construction of buildings, docks, etc.; permit. 
    No person in a park shall: 
(a)  Construct or erect any building or structure of whatever kind upon or across park lands whether permanent or temporary in character. 
(b)  Run, string, or lay any lines, or similar devices into, upon, or across any park lands. 
(Ord. of 6-7-94) 
Sec. 10-57. - Trees, shrubbery, lawns. 
    No person in a park shall damage, cut, carve, transplant or remove any tree or plant or injure the bark, or pick the flowers or seeds of any tree or plant; attach any rope, wire or other contrivance to any tree or plant. 
(Ord. of 6-7-94) 
Sec. 10-58. - Wild animals, birds. 
    No person in a park shall hunt, molest, frighten, kill, trap, chase, tease, shoot or throw missiles at any animal, reptile or bird; remove or possess the young of any wild animal, or the eggs or nest or young of any reptile or bird. Feeding alligators is strictly prohibited. 
(Ord. of 6-7-94) 
Sec. 10-59. - Sanitation. 
    No person in the park shall: 
(1)  Throw, discharge or otherwise place or cause to be placed in the waters of any swimming pool, wading pool, fountain, pond, lake, stream, bay or other body of water in or adjacent to any park or any tributary, stream, storm sewer or drain flowing into such waters any substance, matter or thing, liquid or solid, which will or may result in the pollution of the waters. Such pollutants shall include, but not be limited to, soap, detergents, shampoos or chemicals. 
(2)  Dump, deposit or leave any bottles, broken glass, ashes, paper, boxes, cans, dirt, rubbish, waste, garbage, refuse, or other trash, anywhere on the park grounds. Such matter must be placed in proper receptacles where provided. Where receptacles are not provided, all such rubbish or waste shall be carried away from the park by the person responsible for its presence, and properly disposed of elsewhere. 
(Ord. of 6-7-94) 
Sec. 10-60. - Traffic. 
    No person in a park shall: 
(1)  Fail to comply with all provisions of the motor vehicle code of the State of North Carolina, and the ordinances of the city as they regard the operation of motor vehicles in city parks. 
(2)  Fail to follow all directions of any police officer or park employee who is authorized to direct traffic in any park in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and such supplemental regulations as may be issued subsequently. 
(3)  Fail to obey all traffic signs which may be posted to indicate speed limits, parking regulations, stopping, yielding, and all other signs which have been posted for the proper control and safety of persons and property. 
(4)  Operate any vehicle at a speed greater than fifteen (15) miles per hour unless otherwise posted. 
(5)  Drive or park any vehicle on any road, street or parking area, other than an established road, street or parking area, and such use shall be in accordance with all posted regulations, or at the direction of any traffic officer or park officer [employee] present. 
(6)  Operate any go-cart, minibike, three or four wheel ATV or any other unlicensed motor vehicle, except in such places, if any, that have been designated for that purpose. 
(Ord. of 6-7-94; Ord. No. 01-08-02, 10-1-02) 
Sec. 10-61. - Picnic areas. 
(1)  Police and park employees shall have the authority to regulate the activities in such areas, when necessary, to prevent congestion and to secure a park area's maximum use for the comfort and convenience of the public. 
(2)  No person in a park shall picnic or lunch in a place other than designated picnic areas. 
(Ord. of 6-7-94; Ord. No. 01-08-02, 10-1-02) 
Sec. 10-62. - Fires, flammable material. 
(1)  No person shall build a fire in any park. No person shall throw or otherwise scatter lighted matches, burning cigarettes or cigars, tobacco paper or other flammable material within any park area. 
(2)  Cooking appliances that are fueled by a liquid petroleum is allowed. However, cooking appliances that use any other fuel medium is strictly prohibited. 
(3)  The use of fireworks, or any form of pyrotechnics, is prohibited within the park areas of Boiling Spring Lakes. 
(Ord. of 6-7-94) 
Sec. 10-63. - Disturbing, interfering with others. 
    No person in a park shall: 
(1)  Engage in any violent conduct or conduct which, by its nature, creates the imminent threat of fighting or other violence. 
(2)  Make or use any utterance, gesture, display or abusive language which is intended or likely to provoke retaliation and thereby cause a breach of the peace. 
(Ord. of 6-7-94) 
Sec. 10-64. - Pets. 
    There shall be no pets or other domesticated animals allowed in the public parks except in designated areas. 
    North Lake Park: 
(a)  Leashed dogs are allowed at North Lake Park; no other animals or unleashed dogs are permitted. 
(b)  All dogs must display current rabies tags. 
(c)  Owners shall be required to clean up after their dogs and to dispose of the waste in an appropriate receptacle. 
    A violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
    Violation of this section may subject the offender to civil penalties that have been established to cover the cost of enforcement of this section in accordance with section 1-15 of this Code. The civil penalty shall be as published in the fee schedule adopted by the board of commissioners and modified from time to time. 
(Ord. of 6-7-94; Res. No. 2007-20, § 1, 6-5-07; Res. No. 2008-24, 7-1-08) 
Sec. 10-65. - Entering closed park areas; disregarding posted notices. 
    No person shall enter any park area posted as closed to the public, nor shall any person use or abet the use of any park area in violation of posted notices. 
(Ord. of 6-7-94) 
Sec. 10-66. - Alcoholic beverages, illegal substances. 
    No person in a park shall: 
(1)  Possess any malt beverage or unfortified wine, as defined in Chapter 18B of the General Statutes of the State of North Carolina. 
(2)  Possess any fortified wine or spirituous liquor, as defined in Chapter 18B of the General Statutes of the State of North Carolina. 
(3)  Possess, use or consume any controlled substance or be under the influence of any controlled substance, except as prescribed by a physician. 
(Ord. of 6-7-94; Res. of 6-8-99) 
Sec. 10-67. - Camping. 
    Camping in the city parks is regulated by special use permit. (See section 10-52, Special use permits.) 
(Ord. of 6-7-94) 
Sec. 10-68. - Prohibition regarding registered sex offenders. 
(a)  Purpose. As a justifiable exercise of the public powers of the City of Boiling Spring Lakes, North Carolina, the city desires to regulate the use of city parks and reduce opportunities for sex offenders to make use of public spaces for criminal intent, thereby maintaining a parks and recreation system that is meant for the peaceful enjoyment of children and other citizens. 
(b)  Definitions. For the purpose of this section, the following definitions shall apply, unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. 
    Sex offender means an individual who is registered (or required to be registered) by any state or federal agency as a sex offender, and whose name is (or should be) published on any state or federal registered sex offender listing, including, but not limited to the sex offender registry established in Article 27a of North Carolina General Statutes, Chapter 14. 
    Public park means any publicly owned or maintained land which is designated by the city as a park or recreation facility. Park property shall include all adjacent parking areas, including any off-street parking spaces adjacent to the park. 
    Severability clause. If any court shall determine that any work, clause, phrase, sentence, paragraph or subsection of this article is unconstitutional as worded, the court shall attempt to construct or interpret such unconstitutional provision so as to enable same to be constitutional as so narrowed or construed. If the court cannot so limit or construe such work or provision narrowly so as to render same constitutional, it shall strike or modify only the minimum number of words, phrases, clauses, sentences, or paragraphs as will be absolutely necessary to render the remaining constitutional. In no case shall a subordinate word, clause or phrase render it's attached major section or provision unconstitutional, but instead shall be severed there from entirely, unless such severance renders the remainder wholly meaningless or unconstitutional. 
(c)  General offense. It shall constitute a general offense against the regulations of the City for any person or persons registered with the State of North Carolina and/or any other state or federal agency (or for any person or persons required to register pursuant to the General Statutes of the State of North Carolina and/or any other state or federal requirement) to knowingly enter into or on any public park owned, operated, or maintained by the city. 
(d)  Exemptions. Occasionally, the North Carolina Department of Corrections will bring prisoners to our city parks to perform community service work, such as cleaning and painting, and it is possible that one or more of the prisoners is a convicted sex offender. Due to the fact that these workers are under armed guard, these workers would be allowed in the city parks during performance of community service work. 
(e)  Penalty. Violation of this section may subject the offender to civil penalties that have been established to cover the cost of enforcement of this section in accordance with section 1-15 of this Code. The civil penalty shall be as published in the fee schedule adopted by the board of commissioners and modified from time to time. Each and every entrance into the parks, regardless of the time period involved shall constitute a separate offense under this section. 
(Ord. No. 2007-21, § A, 6-5-2007; Res. No. 2008-24, 7-1-08) 
Secs. 10-69-10-79. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - LAKES REGULATIONS 

Sec. 10-80. - Swimming or wading. 
    No person in a park shall: 
(1)  Swim or wade in any waters or waterways in or adjacent to any park, except in such waters and at such places as are provided therefore, and in compliance with such regulations as are herein set forth or may be hereafter adopted. 
(a)  Swimming areas open to the public are restricted to the designated areas on Boiling Spring Lake, Seminole Lake, Spring Lake, Take Lake and Mirror Lake. 
(b)  City property owners and/or residents and their guests may use any remaining lakes with a park area adjacent to the lake. Swimming in all other lakes without a designated public park is restricted to bordering property owners, residents, and their guests. 
(c)  The city may, from time to time, grant a special use permit (see section 10-52 and Appendix A) to use designated swimming areas for formal, scheduled swimming or diving classes which shall be open to the public. 
(2)  Frequent any waters or places designated for the purpose of swimming or wading, or congregate thereat, except between the hours of sunrise to one-half hour before sunset. 
(3)  Dress or undress at any bathing area, or in any vehicle, except motor homes, toilet or other place, except in such bathing houses or structures as may be provided for that purpose. 
(4)  Swim in the nude. 
(Ord. of 6-7-94; Res. No. 04-28.1, § 1, 10-5-04; Ord. No. 2007-21, § B, 6-5-2007) 
Editor's note- Appendix A referenced above is not set out in this Code but is on file and available for inspection in the offices of the city. 
Note- Formerly § 10-68. 
Sec. 10-81. - Fishing. 
    Fishing areas open to the public are Boiling Spring Lake, North and Spring Lakes. City property owners and/or residents and their guests may use any remaining lakes with a park area adjacent to the lake. Fishing in all other lakes without a designated public park is restricted to bordering property owners, residents, and their guests. 
    No person in a park shall: 
(1)  Engage in commercial fishing, or the buying or selling of fish caught in any waters within the City of Boiling Spring Lakes. 
(2)  Fish in any waters, except by the use of hook and line, and only in waters specifically designated by the city for that use and under such regulations and restrictions as have been or may be prescribed by the North Carolina Wildlife Resources Commission and the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. of 6-7-94; Ord. No. 2007-21, § B, 6-5-07) 
Note- Formerly § 10-69. 
Sec. 10-82. - Boating and water skiing. 
    The provisions of G.S., para 75A-1 et seq., the "Boating Safety Act," are hereby incorporated by reference and are hereby made a part of the code of ordinances of the city the same as if fully set forth herein. A copy of this Act will be on file at City Hall. 
(1)  [Prohibitions.] No person shall: 
(a)  Bring into or operate any motor-powered boat, jet ski type craft upon any waters, except at places specifically designated for power boating by the city. Such activity shall be in accordance with applicable regulations as are now or may hereafter be adopted. 
(b)  Operate mechanically powered boats on any lake except for the following: Boiling Spring Lake, North Lake and Spring Lake. 
(c)  Operate gas-powered motors on North Lake and Spring Lake. Only electric trolling motors are permitted. No watercraft on Spring Lake may be operated within one hundred (100) feet of the beach on Spring Lake. 
(d)  Operate a power boat, jet ski type craft, or water ski, within fifty (50) feet of any dock or privately owned bulkhead, except to leave or approach a dock in compliance with no-wake zones. 
(e)  Operate any watercraft, power boat, jet-ski type craft or water ski within one hundred (100) feet of the dam or spillway on Boiling Spring Lake. 
(f)  Operate a boat in excess of a recommended length of twenty-five (25) feet on any lake within the City of Boiling Spring Lakes. 
(2)  No-wake zones. Watercraft may not be operated at greater than idle speed in any established no-wake zone. A wake shall be defined as any clear and appreciable wave action caused by the operation of a watercraft that causes any other watercraft or device of any kind, type or description whatsoever to be moved or rocked thereby causing a clear and substantial disturbance and/or damage to any other watercraft, device or the water along any shoreline. 
(a)  It is unlawful to create an appreciable wake in any established No-Wake zone on Boiling Spring Lake. No-wake zones are marked by buoys and exact locations are described in Appendix B, No-Wake Zones. 
(b)  All watercraft pulling skiers shall proceed from outside the established "No-Wake Zones." Upon returning, all vessels pulling skiers shall reduce to "No-Wake" speed when the watercraft enters restricted areas. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful to willfully damage, alter, deface, move or remove any waterway markings, buoys or safety devices. 
(3)  Dangerous operation of watercraft, excessive noise. It is unlawful to: 
(a)  Navigate, direct or handle any watercraft carelessly or heedlessly with willful or wanton disregard for the rights or safety of others. 
(b)  Operate any water craft on any lake without due caution or in a manner so as to endanger or be likely to endanger the occupants of any other watercraft or to cause injury to persons or property through such careless operation. 
(c)  Operate a watercraft that is equipped with over-transoms, open headers, or any device which creates an unreasonable noise, or is of such intensity or duration as to be a nuisance to others or to be detrimental to the life or health of others. (See Section 75.A9 of the "Boating Safety Act" of North Carolina, Muffling Devices.) 
(d)  Operate any experimental or racing type watercraft on Boiling Spring Lake. 
(e)  Engage in any form of powerboat racing on the Boiling Spring Lake. 
(4)  Watercraft Launching Area. (See Appendix C, Boat Ramp Park Area) 
(a)  The dock and launching area shall be restricted to launching and docking watercraft only. No swimming, fishing, sunbathing or picnicking shall be allowed at the dock or adjacent launching area. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to leave a watercraft unattended at the dock or launching area. 
(c)  Watercraft shall be launched and loaded only in areas designated for launching and loading. 
(d)  Water skiing must be started outside of the No-Wake zone. 
(5)  Launch area parking facilities. It shall be unlawful for motor vehicles with watercraft trailers to park in areas other than that designated for vehicles with watercraft trailers to park. It shall be unlawful for motor vehicles without watercraft trailers to park in the area designated for vehicles with watercraft trailers. 
(6)  Penalty. 
(a)  Violation of this section may subject the offender to penalties or fines. The civil penalties have been established to cover the cost of enforcement of this section in accordance with section 1-15 of this Code. The civil penalty shall be as published in the fee schedule adopted by the board of commissioners and modified from time to time. 
(b)  The violation of the boating and water skiing ordinances in this chapter will constitute the indefinite loss of watercraft launching facility privileges. 
(Ord. of 6-7-94; Res. of 11-14-95; Ord. No. 06-01-03, 3-4-03; Ord. No. 2007-21, § B, 6-5-07; Res. No. 2008-24, 7-1-08; Res. No. 2010-09, 4-6-10) 
Editor's note- Appendix B, relative to no-wake zones, and Appendix C, concerning the boat ramp park area, are not set out in this Code but are on file and available for inspection in the offices of the city. 
Note- Formerly § 10-70. 
Sec. 10-83. - Aircraft operation. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to ascend or land with any aircraft, including gliders, balloons, helicopters, flying machines and parachutes within the city limits, or to practice touch and go landings either on land or on the lakes of the city. This prescription shall not apply to emergency landings nor to military or National Guard personnel. This prescription shall not apply to any medical helicopter. This prescription shall not apply to any landing at an established airport. 
(b)  Permission may be granted to the forestry service if the service desires to secure water from the lake for purposes of fire fighting. If the forestry service desires to use the lake for this purpose it must coordinate same with the city police and secure permission for same. 
(c)  Violation of this section may subject the offender to penalties or fines. The civil penalties have been established to cover the cost of enforcement of this section in accordance with section 1-15 of this Code. The civil penalty shall be as published in the fee schedule adopted by the board of commissioners and modified from time to time. 
(Res. of 10-7-97, §§ 1, 2; Res. No. 2001-20, § 1, 10-15-01; Ord. No. 2007-21, § B, 6-5-2007; Res. No. 2008-24, 7-1-08) 
Note- Formerly § 10-71. 
Sec. 10-84. - Irrigation. 
    All property owners bordering on city-owned lakes may use the lake water for irrigation purposes unless otherwise directed by the board of commissioners. 
(Res. of 6-6-01; Ord. No. 2007-21, § B, 6-5-07) 
Note- Formerly § 10-72. 
Chapter 11 - PERSONNEL[1]
